commit_message:
Fix VM provider get_available_providers() test

Fix VM provider get_available_providers() to be able to add new
providers without changing it.

Change-Id: I01167cfe21a2ff5e74bf875649273fef4aa1df03

commit_message:
Adds help text to brocade configuration options

Help text was added to the configuration options defined in the brocade neutron
plugin. This help text should assist users of the brocade plugin. The OSTYPE
configuration option was not used in the plugin and was labeled as such so a
user of the plugin would not worry about the meaning of it.

The example etc file /etc/neutron/plugins/brocade/brocade.ini has been updated
to share the same help values where applicable.

Fixes-Bug: #1157511

Change-Id: Ie068396e77902037a7a0b5334d4dfb0dcdd3575e

commit_message:
Add environment.d/default.yaml

Add environment.d/default.yaml from upstream example; this avoids
ERROR logs when starting heat engine.

'}, {'account_id': 6506, 'date': '2013-06-27 15:34:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Ready For Review'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-06-27 18:13:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Do not merge

Not sure what setting read-only at create time would do for you unless you're executing a clone... but regardless.

I'd be more interested in changing this around to be an attach option and possibly having an extension to do something like modify an existing volume to be read only.

I think this needs some more thought and planning.

Also... not sure what you've got going on with the commit message (reverify no bug)"}, {'account_id': 2861, 'date': '2013-06-28 09:26:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Mentioning this Read Only mode, I think the ACL makes a good foundation. A volume should be changed into readonly by SOMEONE, but not everyone. 
One more thing: if the volume is changed to readonly, does it mean it will be readonly for everyone? Or readonly for someone, and read-write for the super users, like the admins and the volume owner. 
IMO, this readonly blueprint might relate to topics like volume ACL, and different access permissions from different users.'}, {'account_id': 6506, 'date': '2013-06-28 09:58:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Work In Progress

John Griffith, 
I agree with that point that setting read-only at create time may be useless if it's not a clone. But the idea with an attach option is inappropriate, because an user mustn't have an ability to decide what attachment's permissions should be used.

Vincent Hou,
This is a great idea. I'm going to design it and I'll publish it for discuss."}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-06-28 16:37:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Aguzikova,

Not quite what I was getting at, what I was leaning towards was the ability to enable multi-attach, which be default would make any secondary attach commands Read Only.

The point made by Vincent and yourself though sounds great. I'm also limiting things right now to multi-attach where any additional attach commands are allowed but as Read Only.  Future direction might include adding support for R/W as well but there's a number of caveats there that I don't think anybody wants to tackle right now."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-06 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-06 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

'}, {'account_id': 6506, 'date': '2013-07-11 19:22:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Ready For Review

Added dependency on blueprint volume-acl, so I make some #TODO instructions in the code (1 for calculate read_only result, others are in unit tests).'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-07-28 15:50:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'll let Duncan discuss his -2, meanwhile I have a couple of concerns about this approach.

I was actually thinking of something significantly more simple than this, what I had in mind was actually NOT to have all of this complexity in the volume space itself, but actually to just have an attach semantic to instruct the hypervisor or host that the attach should be set to Read Only.

The approach here (while cool) seems to add some unnecessary complexity IMO, particularly considering where we are now and what capabilities we have to deal with this.

The other alternative, is that you just have an extension to mark the volume as R/O via the connector info.  Regardless it just seems like the complexity of permissions and owner etc aren't really needed here."}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-07-29 02:40:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

So jgriffith, DuncanT and aguzikova, would you like take a look on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/38322/ , I think it is the second way which jgriffith mentioned in above comments.'}, {'account_id': 6506, 'date': '2013-08-01 12:44:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Work In Progress

Waiting volume-acl related changes.'}, {'account_id': 8325, 'date': '2013-08-01 14:51:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Code review only'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-09 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-09 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 6506, 'date': '2013-08-15 13:40:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Restored'}, {'account_id': 1330, 'date': '2013-08-20 19:51:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

I think this patch is taking the wrong approach. A proper implementation of read-only would also allow multiple readers. Recording *the* reader of a volume just doesn't make sense, the most you want is a use-count or a list. But if it is read-only, why not allow multiple readers?

Would it make more sense to just deal with read-only as a by-product of multi-attach?"}, {'account_id': 8319, 'date': '2013-08-22 04:00:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: (1 inline comment)

In general any number of users should be able to attach a READ_ONLY volume. I would wait for others' input on the same."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-29 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Abandoned

'}, {'created': '2013-07-07 08:52:20.000000000', 'message': "Add volume permissions like Unix file permissions.

Supporting volume permissions like file permissions in Unix-like
systems:
    for user (volume's owner),
    for group (useless until user groups are implemented in keystone),
    for others;
    'r' - read permissions,
    'w' - write permissions,
    'x' - execute permissions, can be useful the future as boot from
volume permissions.

Supporting Read Only mode for volumes.

While multi-attaching with Read/Write permissions
is not supported, when a volume has been already attached in R/W mode
by `rw_attached_user`, other users can see the volume is available
in only R/O mode despite the permissions they have.

Unit-tests are added too.

blueprint read-only-volumes

Change-Id: I3a09c34129c9635d7d835b5afbd5571d2458045f

Add Read-Only volume attaching support

Supporting Read Only mode for volumes through ACL.

blueprint read-only-volumes

didn't run it because of setup.py's:

setup_requires=['d2to1', 'pbr'],

but code looks good"}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-08-12 16:09:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-08-20 23:55:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Wait a second... I thought that for bulk deletes, you had to issue a DELETE request to the account with ?bulk-delete and a suitable request body. Does this really work with a DELETE to any object or container under that account, too?'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2013-08-21 01:18:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Samuel Merritt:


Your thought is correct. My first idea is adding 'DELETE account' with bulk-delete query string as bulk_delete method.


However current code still works well, because bulk middleware ignores container/object name in URI path, and deletes any containers and objects which are written in request body under that account.


Adding delete_account method may be better way for achieving it. If so, I may plan it later."}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-08-29 21:23:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think it'd be nice if python-swiftclient supported bulk delete; but I don't think this patch really gets us there:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/45423/

1) hanging the bulk delete "support" off delete_object is clunky with the required container and object names
2) not being able to get at and parse the response body sorta defeats the contract in a scary and not great way :\

Because this change adds an akward and error prone interface for a feature that's probably not broadly deployed or understood - I'm inclined to say we're better off sticking to "sorry, not supported yet, but the api is super easy, go read http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/misc.html#module-swift.common.middleware.bulk then grab a copy of requests and knock yourself out!"  (I could be wrong there, just stating an opinion).

@Kota

If you want to pursue this further (and I hope you do) I think my only real requirement would be that the body can come out and be parsed if the caller *wants* to do the right thing.  But I'd prefer to have a new top level method (probably "bulk_delete" and not "delete_account") that can acctually build the body and parses the response (maybe even raising a ClientException).

Good luck.

This is a soft -1, if someone else wants to come along and overrule me please do! (*Is* there a way to safely make a bulk delete request with this interface!?)'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2013-09-03 11:18:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Clay:


OK, I'll rewrite this patch for your suggestion.?Thanks."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-09-11 06:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-09-11 06:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-05 10:17:19.000000000', 'message': "Add bulk_delete method to client library

Allow the ability to use a bulk-delete request
of bulk middleware.

In order to use bulk feature of swift, this patch
adds 'bulk_delete' method to client library.
It requires a list of paths('/container' or
'/container/object') which should be deleted and
will returns response of swift written in json format.
If bulk feature is not supported, this method will fails
with ClientException.

This patch does not modify command line to keep
current behavior such as 'swift delete --all'
because bulk middleware is optional on swift.

Change-Id: Iafb1339a7497acdaf411f1a169752f2f4bcf8db4
"}, {'created': '2013-08-05 12:45:38.000000000', 'message': "Allow sending contents for bulk-delete

Allow the ability to send a contents
in delete_object method for bulk-delete.

Because bulk-delete feature requires request
body(a list of objects which shoud be deleted)
in delete method, this patch enables to send it.

For backward compatibility,
we could use bulk-delete feature only when
setting query_string to be 'bulk-delete' and
also setting contents which includes object paths.

Change-Id: Iafb1339a7497acdaf411f1a169752f2f4bcf8db4
"}, {'created': '2013-08-06 00:41:59.000000000', 'message': "Allow sending contents for bulk-delete

commit_message:
Allow sending contents for bulk-delete

Allow the ability to send a contents
in delete_object method for bulk-delete.

Because bulk-delete feature requires request
body(a list of objects which shoud be deleted)
in delete method, this patch enables to send it.

For backward compatibility,
we could use bulk-delete feature only when
setting query_string to be 'bulk-delete' and
also setting contents which includes object paths.
(When setting both of them, container/object
name of url will be ignored)

Change-Id: Iafb1339a7497acdaf411f1a169752f2f4bcf8db4

"missing" because they're unnecessary'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-09-03 16:52:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Judging from what is said in the bug, it seems only log, local and gettextutils should be added."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2013-09-03 17:09:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

According to the bug report, this is needed to use the update.py script in /oslo-incubator/?

There are other ways to perform updates to a given project using the update.py script. For instance, updating a specific module independently is often recommended instead of updating every dependency in a project since that sync will include functional changes not required by the purpose of the sync (ex. updating crypto for a bug fix but automatically updating db since it is also specified in the /keystone/openstack-common.conf)

This can be done by using the --modules flag of the update.py script instead of *only* using the --config-file ../keystone/openstack-common.conf option. 

This allows us to explicitly define what modules we update."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-09-11 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

subject: Remove sqlalchemy_debug option
messages:
[{'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-08-21 21:25:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The useability of "default_log_levels" as a list config is pretty terrible in my opinion.

The change you propose here could make sense, but it makes me grumpy because we used to have "debug" just turn on sqlalchemy notifications, then folks wanted that changed to produce less logs on test boxes, so I asked them to add this config setting so that we could retain ease of debugging sql statements.'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2013-08-27 00:18:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I think I promote this. It's always kind of weird that we have one-off ways to mess with log levels. I do think that the log level config options could be made more straightforward and still retain full control. So I propose we move towards that. (Like can we please get rid of 'verbose' and 'debug' by just having a freakin root_log_level=DEBUG or something?)

Interested to hear more thoughts on this as I am a newbie."}, {'account_id': 6493, 'date': '2013-09-04 01:00:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-21 20:43:44.000000000', 'message': "Remove sqlalchemy_debug option

This commit removes the sqlalchemy_debug option it was an unnecessary
addition. The Oslo logging module already has an option to specify
log levels for other loggers. By changing the sqlalchemy entry in
the list config option default_log_levels sqlalchemy log level can
be set to debug. There isn't a need for a separate config option to
do this.

Change-Id: I3c8d8f8887c65988751056dedb77f84af3221b24
"}]
commit_message:
Remove sqlalchemy_debug option

This commit removes the sqlalchemy_debug option it was an unnecessary
addition. The Oslo logging module already has an option to specify
log levels for other loggers. By changing the sqlalchemy entry in
the list config option default_log_levels sqlalchemy log level can
be set to debug. There isn't a need for a separate config option to
do this.

Change-Id: I3c8d8f8887c65988751056dedb77f84af3221b24

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I have not validated your specific code, but I developed something similar before pushing: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/27660/

I think adding a joined relationship to the model will be much simpler for the developers of mixin classes.

If your concern is about genericity, I would say that manipulation of models is generic enough.'}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

missing tests'}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Salvatore, I've looked at your change and I think we are talking about different problems here.

This particular change has nothing to do with DB mixins of extensions. It's all about retrieving of related collections using joins (e. g. Network class has 'ports' and 'subnets' attributes. If we call get_networks() it will make (1 + N) queries to DB due to _make_network_dict() method accesses those attributes, and they are lazy loaded).

But it's fairly easy to modify generic _get_collection() method to 'preload' fields that are queried using joins (as there is no sense to joinload a collection if we are not going to use it). And thus all methods directly or indirectly using _get_collection() would receive a speed up 'for free' (without any modification at all).

If we rarely access collection attributes, it would actually be better to avoid joins and load them lazily, and we can explicitly turn the joinedload off (or enable joinedload only for a subset of attributes) by passing a specified argument to _get_collection() method.

So I think this can actually be useful."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/27697/2/check/gate-quantum-pep8/6927 : SUCCESS in 00:01:39

- http://logs.openstack.org/27697/2/check/gate-quantum-python27/6547 : SUCCESS in 00:12:35
- http://logs.openstack.org/27697/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/22067 : SUCCESS in 00:20:54
'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm not sure why we're doing this work.  Why not leverage SQLAlchemy's builtin support for this?  We should be able to update the model definitions to get the gains we desire.


http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_0_7/orm/relationships.html#configuring-self-referential-eager-loading"}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Restored'}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Mark, we surely could update the model definitions to use joined load of specified relationships, but in that case
those relationships would always be joined when we query a parent model, even if we don't use them at all (unless we specify the lazyload() option of course).

I think, it's perfectly fine to use SQLAlchemy Query.options() when we query a parent model and explicitly specify what attributes should be loaded eagerly and what should be loaded lazily by hand (as at this place of code
the developer knows what strategy should be used depending what his/her code does further with retrieved data). 

But there are also cases, when we don't query the model directly, but rather use an auxiliary method (e. g. get_networks()). In this case the developer just can't specify Query.options() as he/she doesn't have access to a Query instance.

I believe, there could be situations when the developer don't want relationships to be loaded by applying of a join
(e. g. 1) I want to retrieve just ids of networks using of get_networks() or 2) a relationship attribute of this model is accessed rarely depending on some esoteric condition).

You could argue, that get_networks() and similar methods accept the fields argument and the developer could omit a relationship field when calling the method, but in fact it's rather useless: all fields of a model are queried first and then dict_func process only queried fields. So if we specified relationships to be join loaded in the model definition, that would led to a complex query using a LEFT OUTER JOIN, even if those fields weren't queried.

I believe, an additional interface for specifying of loading strategy in case of using of such auxiliary functions could actually be useful."}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rebased'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'message': "Provide a way to load collections using joins

It is a common pattern in our code to retrieve a collection using a
model specific method (e. g. get_networks()/get_subnets()/etc) and
process its elements in for loop. However, this is not very database
friendly if the model has related collections  that are lazy loaded
(i. e. they are loaded by making an additional select query on
attribute access), because this leads to (1 + N) queries to DB.

We could actually analyze the list of queried fields and force
loading of related collection using LEFT OUTER JOIN. This makes
the original query more complex but prevents us from making of
additional N queries.

The idea here is to modify generic _get_collection() method so that
the caller may force it to use 'joinedload' strategy in different ways:
    - use 'joinedload' for loading of all related collections that are queried
    - set the default strategy of related collections loading to be 'joined'
    - disable 'joinedload' and load related collections lazily on attribute access

Thus all methods directly or indirectly (by calling of get_networks()/get_subnets()/etc)
calling _get_collection() method would automatically take benefit of this change.

Fixes bug 1174192.

Change-Id: I62bf235ab0a0f06f9b6e5831050d1907593c4b4c
"}, {'created': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'message': "Provide a way to load collections using joins

It is a common pattern in our code to retrieve a collection using a
model specific method (e. g. get_networks()/get_subnets()/etc) and
process its elements in for loop. However this is not very database
friendly if the model has related collections  that are lazy loaded
(i. e. they are loaded by making an additional select query on
attribute access), because this leads to (1 + N) queries to DB.

We can actually analyze the list of queried fields and force
loading of related collection using LEFT OUTER JOIN. This makes
the original query more complex but prevents us from making of
additional N queries.

The idea is to modify generic _get_collection() method so that
a caller may force it to use 'joinedload' strategy in different
ways: use 'joinedload' for loading of specified related collections,
use 'joinedload' for loading of all related collections that
are queried, disable 'joinedload' and load related collections lazily
on attribute access.

Fixes bug 1174192.

Change-Id: I62bf235ab0a0f06f9b6e5831050d1907593c4b4c
"}, {'created': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'message': "Provide a way to load collections using joins

    - disable 'joinedload' and load related collections lazily on attribute access

Thus all methods directly or indirectly (by calling of get_networks()/get_subnets()/etc)
calling _get_collection() method would automatically take benefit of this change.

Fixes bug 1174192.

Change-Id: I62bf235ab0a0f06f9b6e5831050d1907593c4b4c
"}, {'created': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'message': "Provide a way to load collections using joins

It is a common pattern in our code to retrieve a collection using a
model specific method (e. g. get_networks()/get_subnets()/etc) and
process its elements in for loop. However, this is not very database
friendly if the model has related collections  that are lazy loaded
(i. e. they are loaded by making an additional select query on
attribute access), because this leads to (1 + N) queries to DB.

We could actually analyze the list of queried fields and force
loading of related collection using LEFT OUTER JOIN. This makes
the original query more complex but prevents us from making of
additional N queries.

The idea here is to modify generic _get_collection() method so that
the caller may force it to use 'joinedload' strategy in different ways:
    - use 'joinedload' for loading of all related collections that are queried
    - set the default strategy of related collections loading to be 'joined'
    - disable 'joinedload' and load related collections lazily on attribute access

Thus all methods directly or indirectly (by calling of get_networks()/get_subnets()/etc)
calling _get_collection() method would automatically take benefit of this change.

Fixes bug 1174192.

Change-Id: I62bf235ab0a0f06f9b6e5831050d1907593c4b4c
"}, {'created': '2013-07-08 13:51:35.000000000', 'message': "Provide a way to load collections using joins

It is a common pattern in our code to retrieve a collection using a
model specific method (e. g. get_networks()/get_subnets()/etc) and
process its elements in for loop. However, this is not very database
friendly if the model has related collections  that are lazy loaded
(i. e. they are loaded by making an additional select query on
attribute access), because this leads to (1 + N) queries to DB.

We could actually analyze the list of queried fields and force
loading of related collection using LEFT OUTER JOIN. This makes
the original query more complex but prevents us from making of
additional N queries.

The idea here is to modify generic _get_collection() method so that
the caller may force it to use 'joinedload' strategy in different ways:
    - use 'joinedload' for loading of all related collections that are queried
    - set the default strategy of related collections loading to be 'joined'
    - disable 'joinedload' and load related collections lazily on attribute access

Thus all methods directly or indirectly (by calling of get_networks()/get_subnets()/etc)
calling _get_collection() method would automatically take benefit of this change.

Fixes bug 1174192.

Change-Id: I62bf235ab0a0f06f9b6e5831050d1907593c4b4c
"}, {'created': '2013-08-02 13:16:31.000000000', 'message': 'Allow to specify the relations loading strategy

It is a common pattern in our code to retrieve a collection using a
model specific method (e. g. get_networks()/get_subnets()/etc) and
process its elements in for loop. However, this is not very database
friendly if the model has related collections  that are lazy loaded
(i. e. they are loaded by making an additional select query on
attribute access), because this leads to (1 + N) queries to DB.

SQLAlchemy provides a very flexible model which allows one to specify
how related instances should be loaded. Though, we have a few auxiliary
methods that hide the underlying Query instance, so it is not possible
to set the relations loading strategy to be used (e. g. _get_collection).

This patch adds an additional argument to _get_collection() (and
corresponding methods of resources) to let caller specify, how related
instances are loaded. The default strategy for loading of collections is
set to be SUBQUERY, which is more efficient than JOINED for querying large
number of entries.

Fixes bug 1174192

Change-Id: I62bf235ab0a0f06f9b6e5831050d1907593c4b4c
'}]
commit_message:
Allow to specify the relations loading strategy

It is a common pattern in our code to retrieve a collection using a
model specific method (e. g. get_networks()/get_subnets()/etc) and
process its elements in for loop. However, this is not very database
friendly if the model has related collections  that are lazy loaded
(i. e. they are loaded by making an additional select query on
attribute access), because this leads to (1 + N) queries to DB.

SQLAlchemy provides a very flexible model which allows one to specify
how related instances should be loaded. Though, we have a few auxiliary
methods that hide the underlying Query instance, so it is not possible
to set the relations loading strategy to be used (e. g. _get_collection).

This patch adds an additional argument to _get_collection() (and
corresponding methods of resources) to let caller specify, how related
instances are loaded. The default strategy for loading of collections is
set to be SUBQUERY, which is more efficient than JOINED for querying large
number of entries.

Fixes bug 1174192

Change-Id: I62bf235ab0a0f06f9b6e5831050d1907593c4b4c

commit_message:
String substitution of values in DictOpt

Support of PEP 292 string substitution for values in the key/value
pairs of DictOpt. Modified _substitute method to recognize dictionary
instances.

Change-Id: Ia565caabcc8814d3a06ed46b73989bcd3edb7ca6
Implements: blueprint oslo-config-dictopt-string-substitution

I like where this is going.

Was wondering about a couple of things:

1. Could you move the backends to swift/account/backend.py and swift/container/backend.py instead of sharing the same module in common/backends.py?

  It seems like they should live next to the server code.

2. Can you move the unit tests for the backends to their own test module instead of leaving them in test_db.py?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-28 04:07:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-28 03:44:51.000000000', 'message': 'Split backends.py off swift/common/db.py

The main purpose of this patch is to lay groundwork for automated
documentation of Pluggable Back-ends (formerly known as "small LFS").
Everything in backends.py is API: has its docstrings published
as such, and is available to Swift core as an import. What remains
in db.py is not an API.

Aside from docstrings, one also can easily tell the remaining API
violations just by grepping for 'swift\.common\.db'.

Note that in Python it's extremely tempting to use things which
were not documented as an API, as long as they are available in
a namespace. This is why this patch, for instance, has backend.py
import utf8encode() from db.py even though there aren't any users
of it left in db.py itself.

We have a raft of changes to docstrings staged for later, but this
patch takes care to relocate ContainerBroker and AccountBroker into
their new home intact.

Change-Id: Ibab5c7605860ab768c8aa5a3161a705705689b04
'}, {'created': '2013-08-29 01:53:15.000000000', 'message': 'Split backends.py off swift/common/db.py

implementations. The backend.py files will eventually be the module
where the backend APIs are defined via docstrings of this reference
implementation. The swift/common/db.py module will remain an internal
module used by the reference implementation.

We have a raft of changes to docstrings staged for later, but this
patch takes care to relocate ContainerBroker and AccountBroker into
their new home intact.

commit_message:
Split backends off swift/common/db.py

The main purpose of this patch is to lay the groundwork for allowing
the container and account servers to optionally use pluggable backend
implementations. The backend.py files will eventually be the module
where the backend APIs are defined via docstrings of this reference
implementation. The swift/common/db.py module will remain an internal
module used by the reference implementation.

We have a raft of changes to docstrings staged for later, but this
patch takes care to relocate ContainerBroker and AccountBroker into
their new home intact.

Change-Id: Ibab5c7605860ab768c8aa5a3161a705705689b04

commit_message:
Make some heat resolve functions workable in hot

Make resolve functions Ref, Fn::GetAtt, Fn::Replace workable in hot.

Fixes bug #1221017

Change-Id: I9b7ca58720b3c7d157c79c3756510ebc62d81ee5

[{'created': '2013-09-04 03:11:55.000000000', 'message': 'Only calculate ETag on read if we have an ETag

If we do not have an ETag stored in the metadata of the object, there
is no point spending the time to calculate it for GETs.

Change-Id: I5032251414eceb38079d235504cc9e589dea5f3e
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2013-09-04 03:50:29.000000000', 'message': 'Assume ETag is always in the metadata

Currently the GET and HEAD calls always assume that the ETag is present in the
on-disk metadata, as they index the metadata dictionary directly for the value
to fill in the proper response header (a KeyError would be thrown if missing
and turn into a 503).

The close code that handles quarantining checked to see if an ETag is present
in the metadata before making the comparison. However, a close operation would
never even be attempted if an ETag was not present, since the response headers
are filled in before the object is read.

Change-Id: I5032251414eceb38079d235504cc9e589dea5f3e
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2013-09-10 02:26:53.000000000', 'message': 'Assume ETag is always in the metadata

commit_message:
Assume ETag is always in the metadata

Currently the GET and HEAD calls always assume that the ETag is
present in the on-disk metadata, as they index the metadata dictionary
directly for the value to fill in the proper response header (a
KeyError would be thrown if missing and turn into a 503).

The close code that handles quarantining checked to see if an ETag is
present in the metadata before making the comparison. However, a close
operation would never even be attempted if an ETag was not present,
since the response headers are filled in before the object is read.

Change-Id: I5032251414eceb38079d235504cc9e589dea5f3e
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2013-09-10 02:13:17.000000000', 'message': "Reduce churn of cache on revocation_list

The explicit call to refresh will cause higher-than-average load
under high counts of revocation events.  The simple invalidate ensures
that we don't re-generate the revocation list on revocation event
but only on-demand.

closes-bug: 1220359
Change-Id: I826778843e344be001bbcc832054a0ad446285e7
"}]
commit_message:
Reduce churn of cache on revocation_list

The explicit call to refresh will cause higher-than-average load
under high counts of revocation events.  The simple invalidate ensures
that we don't re-generate the revocation list on revocation event
but only on-demand.

closes-bug: 1220359
Change-Id: I826778843e344be001bbcc832054a0ad446285e7

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-10 23:41:16.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Swift: configure Ceilometer when it is enabled"

This reverts commit f208aafa35996c98de40c1388bbebf326ab2ed20. This
commit broke swift functional tests because the ceilometer middleware
changes HTTP 404 responses into zero byte responses. This results in
BadStatusLine exceptions. Back out the use of ceilometer middleware
until it can be fixed.

Change-Id: Ie25269b58334c40dc1ecae985326af1cf29c3af4
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Swift: configure Ceilometer when it is enabled"

This reverts commit f208aafa35996c98de40c1388bbebf326ab2ed20. This
commit broke swift functional tests because the ceilometer middleware
changes HTTP 404 responses into zero byte responses. This results in
BadStatusLine exceptions. Back out the use of ceilometer middleware
until it can be fixed.

Change-Id: Ie25269b58334c40dc1ecae985326af1cf29c3af4

commit_message:
Add @services decorator

This commit adds a new decorator used for specifying service tags for
a test. It just wraps the attr decorator but before adding the attr it
checks to make sure a valid service name was used.

Part of bp add-service-tags

Change-Id: I0cdf3f5c703a5e4573b8e9b26fb8ede9b6d77690

commit_message:
Remove order dependence from network_basic_ops

There is no guarantee on runtime order for tests, however
test_network_basic_ops had a separate test case for each step in
the scenario being run. This commit just changes the test structure
to individually run the steps of the test scenario inside a single
test method.

Change-Id: I729959b7a11a4c4413c3a7c262318725c56871c1

commit_message:
Remove live migration logic from nova scheduler

Now live migration logic has been moved to conductor, so there is
no need to keep live migration logic in nova scheduler for now.

The fix was remove live migration logic from nova scheduler to make
it more clean.

Change-Id: Icea3d73c23f1fae4bc3e7eeba066d128c0a5f220

which added two same classes ImageDownloadModuleMetaDataError to
exception.py, clear it now.

fixes bug 1223165

commit_message:
Removed duplicated class in exception.py

This commit 6f9ed562d5f6df1dc16029dcaffd4d2e6601099d had a mistake
which added two same classes ImageDownloadModuleMetaDataError to
exception.py, clear it now.

fixes bug 1223165
Change-Id: I2e7a30a63ab24d1ffb9f33a14db65c6fb3594cb0

John,

Responded to your comments.  You are right about the exception issue.  My system was on downlevel code.

I think you are right on the HyperV issue.  It shouldn't be an issue.

I have been thinking about Winston's issue.  I think there are maybe 3 ways we can go.  1) Leave it as is.  Probably not the best choice.  2) Catch the case where the disk_format is not set and treat it the same as a non-RAW image.  The problem with this approach is that I think it will require some changes in unit tests to make that work.  Not the end of the world though.  3) We handle the undefined disk_format like the image is RAW, but that doesn't seem right given that the function is fetch_to_raw and we can't guarantee that the result of copying the volume is a volume in the RAW format.  So, option two would probably be best."}, {'account_id': 752, 'date': '2013-09-01 16:06:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: No score

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-12 18:03:57.000000000', 'message': "Add raw_images_only option to image_utils.py

Some platforms, particularly PowerPC systems running RHEL,
do not have qemu-img installed by default and do not
support image formats other than RAW.  For these systems,
functions/drivers that use fetch_to_raw() currently fail
because it is assumed that qemu-img will always be installed.

This change updates fetch_to_raw() to function more like the
upload_volume() function which checks the image format and skips
any conversion if the image is already in the RAW format. To
minimize the impact the change is being implemented with the
addition of the 'raw_images_only' option.  Only systems that
have that option enabled will skip the need for qemu-img to
check the image format.

DocImpact

fixes bug 1200800

Change-Id: I34540dfa238a8b8e61ff5c30c7e121130bad39b4

"}, {'created': '2013-08-23 21:50:57.000000000', 'message': 'Add check for qemu-img to image_utils fetch_to_raw

Some platforms, particularly PowerPC systems running RHEL,
do not have qemu-img installed by default and do not
support image formats other than RAW.  For these systems,
functions/drivers that use fetch_to_raw() currently fail
because it is assumed that qemu-img will always be installed.

This change updates fetch_to_raw() to function more like the
upload_volume() function which checks the image format and skips
any conversion if the image is already in the RAW format. To
minimize the impact upon platforms that have qemu-img installed
this is being implemented by checking to see if qemu-img is
installed.  If it is installed, no changes are made to the flow
through fetch_to_raw.  If qemu-img is not available and the image
format is not already RAW, an exception is thrown.  Otherwise,
the image is downloaded and we do not progress to the portions of
fetch_to_raw that require qemu-img to be installed.

fixes bug 1200800

Change-Id: I34540dfa238a8b8e61ff5c30c7e121130bad39b4

commit_message:
Add check for qemu-img to image_utils fetch_to_raw

Some platforms, particularly PowerPC systems running RHEL,
do not have qemu-img installed by default and do not
support image formats other than RAW.  For these systems,
functions/drivers that use fetch_to_raw() currently fail
because it is assumed that qemu-img will always be installed.

This change updates fetch_to_raw() to function more like the
upload_volume() function which checks the image format and skips
any conversion if the image is already in the RAW format. To
minimize the impact upon platforms that have qemu-img installed
this is being implemented by checking to see if qemu-img is
installed.  If it is installed, no changes are made to the flow
through fetch_to_raw.  If qemu-img is not available and the image
format is not already RAW, an exception is thrown.  Otherwise,
the image is downloaded and we do not progress to the portions of
fetch_to_raw that require qemu-img to be installed.

This commit also updates the test cases that touch this code.

Closes-bug: 1200800

Change-Id: I34540dfa238a8b8e61ff5c30c7e121130bad39b4

commit_message:
Use format instead of % for string formatting

As part of keeping Marconi forward compatible, this change replaces
the usage of % for string formatting with .format.

Change-Id: Ie2b1c95f4527339953aa57cceb9b39b0988bef26

commit_message:
Move functional tests into wsgi/v1

As per previous discussions and decisions, functional tests should
respect a $transport/$version structure. This patch moves existing tests
under wsgi/v1.

Implements blueprint: refactor-system-tests

Change-Id: I2ffae134fdc42af92c6791ce6cf3600e61096683

commit_message:
Implement small http client for tests

Instead of an HTTP module, use an http client that can be instantiated
once per test and uses requests' sessions. This reduces the code needed
for tests and centralizes the serialization process.

Implements blueprint: refactor-system-tests

Change-Id: I96ec90afb18e3fd0249bc323c85fb216c5878d4d

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-02 17:22:23.000000000', 'message': "Implement embedded marconi-server execution

This patch embeds a marconi-server as part of functional tests in order
to be able to run them when there's not an up-and-running marconi-server

commit_message:
Implement embedded marconi-server execution

This patch embeds a marconi-server as part of functional tests in order
to be able to run them when there's not an up-and-running marconi-server
instance. This is the default behavior, however, it is possible to run
this tests against a remote marconi-server by setting `run_server =
False` in functional-tests.conf and setting the correct marconi-server
url and version.

Implements blueprint: refactor-system-tests

Change-Id: I6795092b2110a02808eac0117979ee1a9a5f9ee2

commit_message:
Slight refactoring of the testcase for Tester.run()

This is a slight refactoring of the test case for the utils.Tester.run()
method which removes code duplicate and adds one extra assertion (the method
is a really central one for Rally and should be carefully tested).

Blueprint test-engine

Change-Id: Ibcef9637b17d181dd4cff5656d510de24a600a1c

subject: Implement -k option for cfn-get-metadata
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-09 13:32:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- gate-heat-cfntools-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/83/45683/1/check/gate-heat-cfntools-pep8/e523ea2 : SUCCESS in 24s
- gate-heat-cfntools-python26 http://logs.openstack.org/83/45683/1/check/gate-heat-cfntools-python26/916e876 : SUCCESS in 31s
- gate-heat-cfntools-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/83/45683/1/check/gate-heat-cfntools-python27/d6ff1b0 : SUCCESS in 51s
'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-09-09 21:57:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This is not part of the original CloudFormation tool cfn-get-metadata, so I see this as a native feature. Also, -k is already taken for the access key in cfn-get-metadata, so this would create a difficult problem to resolve. (source: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/cfn-get-metadata.html).

heat-cfntools are meant to maintain compatibility with CFN, but native things are best done in native tools.

There is a native openstack tool that is designed for this, os-collect-config. It has a bug preventing easy 'print the metadata access', but that should be fairly easy to fix. Given that I'm going to be suggesting we not enhance heat-cfntools beyond cfn compatibility, I'd prefer to see this feature land in os-collect-config, rather than heat-cfntools. However, I would accept the feature into heat-cfntools without the -k, because it would probably make a few things simpler for a few people. :)"}, {'account_id': 6794, 'date': '2013-09-10 07:45:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for taking time to review, Clint!

In fact, the AWS doc is inconsistent (once again). If you read carefully the first paragraph, it says: 'You can also print a sub-tree of the metadata block if the you specify a key. However, only top-level keys are supported'. The "--access-key|k key" is a typo and should read "--key|-k key". 

Again looking at the AWS CFN code (aws-cfn-bootstrap-1.3/bin/cfn-get-metadata):
<snip>
parser.add_option("-k", "--key", help="Retrieve the value at <key> in the Metadata object; must be in dotted object notation (parent.child.leaf)",
                  type="string", dest="key")   
"-k", "--key", help="Retrieve the value at <key> in the Metadata object; must be in dotted object notation (parent.child.leaf)"
<snip>

I didn't know about os-collect-config, I'll have a look and will try to propose a patch there too.'}, {'account_id': 6794, 'date': '2013-09-10 13:57:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-10 13:58:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- gate-heat-cfntools-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/83/45683/2/check/gate-heat-cfntools-pep8/87ea3e1 : SUCCESS in 16s
- gate-heat-cfntools-python26 http://logs.openstack.org/83/45683/2/check/gate-heat-cfntools-python26/f8b73e8 : SUCCESS in 22s
- gate-heat-cfntools-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/83/45683/2/check/gate-heat-cfntools-python27/819ff20 : SUCCESS in 21s
'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-09-10 15:19:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks for the detailed explanation Simon. It might be good to report the inconsistency to AWS.'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-09-10 21:35:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-10 21:35:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-10 21:36:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build succeeded.

- gate-heat-cfntools-python26 http://logs.openstack.org/83/45683/2/gate/gate-heat-cfntools-python26/e520ea1 : SUCCESS in 26s
- gate-heat-cfntools-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/83/45683/2/gate/gate-heat-cfntools-python27/d93a397 : SUCCESS in 23s

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-09 13:31:56.000000000', 'message': 'Implement -k option for cfn-get-metadata

The -k argument can be a top-level key or a nested key in which case
the keys are separated by dots (eg "foo.bar"). In case a key contains a
dot character, it needs to be surrounded by single quotes (eg
"foo.'bar.1'.fred).
If the -k option is not provided, the command prints out the full
metadata structure as before.

Change-Id: Ib05d39672086001b83e8d7f56bc42cc4ba75751c
Fixes: bug #1183299
'}, {'created': '2013-09-10 13:57:39.000000000', 'message': 'Implement -k option for cfn-get-metadata

The -k argument can be a top-level key or a nested key in which case
the keys are separated by dots (eg "foo.bar"). In case a key contains a
dot character, it needs to be surrounded by single quotes (eg
"foo.'bar.1'.fred).
If the -k option is not provided, the command prints out the full
metadata structure as before.

Change-Id: Ib05d39672086001b83e8d7f56bc42cc4ba75751c
Fixes: bug #1183299
'}]
commit_message:
Implement -k option for cfn-get-metadata

The -k argument can be a top-level key or a nested key in which case
the keys are separated by dots (eg "foo.bar"). In case a key contains a
dot character, it needs to be surrounded by single quotes (eg
"foo.'bar.1'.fred).
If the -k option is not provided, the command prints out the full
metadata structure as before.

Change-Id: Ib05d39672086001b83e8d7f56bc42cc4ba75751c
Fixes: bug #1183299

commit_message:
Revert "hacking should conform with OS requirements"

Pinning six for ceilo has messed everything up, for the sake of getting
things unblocked, unpin six, at least for now.

This reverts commit e83339e5dcb210eb3d97f4de70096321748851cb.

Change-Id: Id7a5b8e2fe7a29714cf087d34d9e0f1207906f3d

[{'created': '2013-09-10 09:42:50.000000000', 'message': "Drop the *.create.start notification for Neutron

Based on current implement, there is no resource id assigned
when *.create.start notification sending, so Ceilometer will
run into KeyError. So this fix will drop the *.create.start
notification because the meter can't be linked to correct
resource. Besides the info can be collected by *.create.end.

Fixes bug 1222737

Change-Id: I785ae1ca1383dc5f9afbf2ab072a6e1efc582606
"}, {'created': '2013-09-10 09:58:37.000000000', 'message': "Drop the *.create.start notification for Neutron

Based on current implement, there is no resource id assigned
when *.create.start notification sending, so Ceilometer will
run into KeyError. So this fix will drop the *.create.start
notification because the meter can't be linked to correct
resource. Besides the info can be collected by *.create.end.

Fixes bug 1222737

Change-Id: I785ae1ca1383dc5f9afbf2ab072a6e1efc582606

commit_message:
Drop the *.create.start notification for Neutron

Based on current implement, there is no resource id assigned
when *.create.start notification sending, so Ceilometer will
run into KeyError. So this fix will drop the *.create.start
notification because the meter can't be linked to correct
resource. Besides the info can be collected by *.create.end.

Fixes bug 1222737

Change-Id: I785ae1ca1383dc5f9afbf2ab072a6e1efc582606

commit_message:
Update docs.o.o/trunk/index for new manuals

I've added a new section "Use an OpenStack Cloud" and added all manuals.

All URLs should point to current building books - but some book URL
might need to be changed.

I expect that the following URLs will change:
http://docs.openstack.org/cloud-admin/admin-guide-cloud/admin/content/
http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/image-guide/content/

Change-Id: Ib9e41be6b5085635ba193665730e1903bc9de15f

commit_message:
3PAR driver changes for FC Zone Mgr testing

This is just a WIP patch to help with the testing of the FC Zone Manager.
The initialize_connection code of the FC driver needs to be modified
to return an initiator_target_map.

See review https://review.openstack.org/#/c/41772/ and
BP: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/cinder-fc-zone-manager
for details.

Added code to return the initiator target map in terminate connection.

Change-Id: I3277a046993ac562edc7f67280e1b651b4ad931f

commit_message:
Create links between VPN resources

This commit creates cross links between VPN resource
and resolves VPN related resource UUID to its name.
This helps users to track VPN resources.

Closes-Bug: #1222264

This commit also improves an error handling when an error occurs
during retrieving a resource detail via API call.
While previously a detail page without item values is displayed,
now the index page is displayed for such case.

Change-Id: I53e03bf01ad0f359b889115068b1548c9a61ae8d

commit_message:
Show IPSec Site Connection in VPN service detail

IPSec Site connections associated with VPN service are useful information.
Previously the field "VPN Connections" exist but the associated connections
are not displayed.

Closes-Bug: #1222256

Change-Id: I81da5cc6b63463102c3270fead8921bf8c10d11a

commit_message:
Improves VPNaaS detail page templates

* Change "Tenant ID" to "Project ID"
* Move "Name" and "Description" to the top of the detail pages
* Show "None" if "name" or "description" is empty
* Remove colons from item names in the detail pages
* Remove "VPN type" from VPN service detail
* Arrange the order of items with the same as the creation form
* Print peer_cidrs with for loop

Closes-Bug: #1222260

Change-Id: I2293eb4b87179862c52c1c0bd7852a555955e1c0

commit_message:
Sync the defaults of VPNaaS forms with the server-side defaults

Also clears the unnecessary default values of remote peer subnet,
remote peer address, peer id and PSK.

Split IPSec Site connection creation form into two tabs (required
and optional parameters) since it has many parameters.

Closes-Bug: #1222255

Camel-case resource names (e.g., VPNService, IPSecPolicy...) are
replated by names with spaces like "VPN Service", "IPSec Policy"
and so on.

Change-Id: Ie0d77189ab3fc6d0722ece28abced9192ea0740b

Fix bug in _do_create_volume method of Nexenta NFS volume driver.

commit_message:
Fix bug in Nexenta NFS driver _do_create_volume

Fix bug in _do_create_volume method of Nexenta NFS volume driver.
NMS call nms.folder.create doesn't support third argument, that is why
this call changed to nms.folder.create_with_opts.

Closes-Bug: #1221946
Change-Id: I712ee2919f1bd117e7a1691979639689d95adc92

[{'created': '2013-09-09 21:14:44.000000000', 'message': 'hacking should conform with OS requirements

hacking did not make any assumption on which version of six is
installed, therefore hacking pulled in an incompatible six version,
making it impossible to run the tests.

fixes bug 1222706

Change-Id: Icd31caa93587614425036fc4c8d3cfd3a83b6b3c
(cherry picked from commit 664bc299fd4433f723a06933959c6774e53ae697)
'}]
commit_message:
hacking should conform with OS requirements

hacking did not make any assumption on which version of six is
installed, therefore hacking pulled in an incompatible six version,
making it impossible to run the tests.

fixes bug 1222706

Change-Id: Icd31caa93587614425036fc4c8d3cfd3a83b6b3c
(cherry picked from commit 664bc299fd4433f723a06933959c6774e53ae697)

[{'created': '2013-09-10 18:11:54.000000000', 'message': "Adds ability to ignore hacking validations with noqa

Add allownoqa decorator that can be applied to any of the hacking
core functions.  This allows a using application to bypass that
particular hacking validation.  The reason this is being introduced
is because I need to bypass H231 and H233, both Python 3.x
validations.  I need to bypass these so we can run pep8 validations
on the nova XenServer plugins.  XenServer usese Python 2.4 in its
environment and therefore the code won't pass those two or future
Python 3.x validations.

It is understood that a patch to hacking won't be held up or reverted
if it breaks anything Python 2.4 related, including breaking of this
patch.

Change-Id: Iea3867b84212ab30bdd168b5dbd43c11a4dc535e
(cherry picked from commit 00348dfbe4a3b80c94415d7404a4be1f421bd46e)

commit_message:
This resolves issues in the tests under PyPy

Adds ability to ignore hacking validations with noqa

Add allownoqa decorator that can be applied to any of the hacking
core functions.  This allows a using application to bypass that
particular hacking validation.  The reason this is being introduced
is because I need to bypass H231 and H233, both Python 3.x
validations.  I need to bypass these so we can run pep8 validations
on the nova XenServer plugins.  XenServer usese Python 2.4 in its
environment and therefore the code won't pass those two or future
Python 3.x validations.

It is understood that a patch to hacking won't be held up or reverted
if it breaks anything Python 2.4 related, including breaking of this
patch.

Change-Id: Iea3867b84212ab30bdd168b5dbd43c11a4dc535e

Hi Bob,

Why only ML2 support - I thought also OVS and LinuxBridge were covered by the L3 service plugin.

Please do not merge before the neutron patch is merged.'}, {'account_id': 162, 'date': '2013-09-06 11:54:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Nachi proposed that I exclude OVS from the Neutron patch and instead used ML2 plugin to avoid the gating failures.

I also think that OVS, LB and ML2 are good candidates to delegate L3 routing to service plugin. I discussed briefly with Kyle about this. The sum of that was that since core dev availability for reviewing is scarce I kept the change it to the ML2 plugin.
 
I suggest you and the other core devs decide which plugins to include. Then I will change the patch accordingly.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-09-06 13:45:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

lets clean up the whitespace issue"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-09-06 13:48:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Bob,

I am fine with ML2 only in this patch.
We can push other patches for the other plugin.

I was wondering if you found any issue with ovs & the l3 service plugin; but this appears not to be the case.'}, {'account_id': 6524, 'date': '2013-09-06 21:01:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

[{'created': '2013-09-10 08:05:41.000000000', 'message': "Do not build all books if only www/ is changed

We do not validate the contents of www/ directory and if only files
in it get updated, all the books get build.

Let's do a quick exit for the case of changing only www/.

Change-Id: I05fd5ae58f9351d3d78788f4fe5bbb1e082fb183
"}]
commit_message:
Do not build all books if only www/ is changed

We do not validate the contents of www/ directory and if only files
in it get updated, all the books get build.

Let's do a quick exit for the case of changing only www/.

Change-Id: I05fd5ae58f9351d3d78788f4fe5bbb1e082fb183

commit_message:
Run functional tests under tox

This patch allows to run functional tests under tox, however, they are
disabled by default. In order to run tests with tox, it is necessary to
enable them by modifying the functional-tests.conf and setting run_tests
to True.

This patch also merged both test files in a single one
(test-requirements.txt)

blueprint refactor-system-tests

Change-Id: Iba440b12653cf9ee1454022830107a06b8a7bea9

[{'created': '2013-09-09 21:12:52.000000000', 'message': "Redirect stderr for git rev-parse

If not in a git directory the git warning messages will be printed.
These warnings shouldn't be shown to users and can make things
confusing.

Change-Id: I6b872a7407141edeed33ac6157022743a2919f6d
(cherry picked from commit 029044826668b347cd1d84c4490dc8cb9ca6ac1e)

commit_message:
Redirect stderr for git rev-parse

If not in a git directory the git warning messages will be printed.
These warnings shouldn't be shown to users and can make things
confusing.

Change-Id: I6b872a7407141edeed33ac6157022743a2919f6d
(cherry picked from commit 029044826668b347cd1d84c4490dc8cb9ca6ac1e)

commit_message:
Removes extra /admin/ from building of admin-guide-cloud

The bug is caused by the file being copied to
docs.openstack.org/local/admin-cloud-guide
instead of docs.openstack.org/admin-cloud-guide

Removing <release.path.name></release.path.name> to
fix the bug.

Change-Id: I23c124e33af177059bed809056683e6f98da6a6a
Closes-bug: 1223065

"}, {'created': '2013-08-21 15:05:03.000000000', 'message': "Add support for os-assisted-volume-snapshots

This patch adds support for the assisted volume snapshots API extension.
This is used by Cinder to ask Nova to perform a volume snapshot on its
behalf.  It's required when the volume is actually file backed (like
qcow2) and the hypervisor needs to be involved in the snapshot
operation.

This is done by adding some additional information to the standard
create/delete snapshot APIs.

There is some additional logic included to detect the presence of this
API extension and only attempt if it is present.  This is quite
impotant, because if the API extension is *not* present, Nova will proxy
the snapshot request to the Cinder API, resulting in infinite recursion.

This API extension is only exposed via the compute admin API by default
(adminURL in the keystone service catalog).

Required for blueprint qemu-assisted-snapshots

Co-authored-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I50ee9bf92c8de98528638d1724fe35e07bed729e
"}, {'created': '2013-08-23 15:09:44.000000000', 'message': "Add support for os-assisted-volume-snapshots

commit_message:
Add support for os-assisted-volume-snapshots

This patch adds support for the assisted volume snapshots API extension.
This is used by Cinder to ask Nova to perform a volume snapshot on its
behalf.  It's required when the volume is actually file backed (like
qcow2) and the hypervisor needs to be involved in the snapshot
operation.

Required for blueprint qemu-assisted-snapshots

Change-Id: I50ee9bf92c8de98528638d1724fe35e07bed729e

[{'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-08-22 11:59:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5174, 'date': '2013-08-22 14:40:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

just one minor nit and a question: long ago guys were talking about moving keypairs to keystone... maybe I missed some decision about this, but if I didn't, I don't see a point into turning this a core api.

commit_message:
Makes v3 API keypairs extension core

Adds os-keypairs to the core list for the V3 API.

Rename os-keypairs to keypairs as part of this change.

Fixes some incorrect urls in test_keypairs which still included
the tenant id

Updates api samples for servers since keypairs is now core and forms
part of the response by default

+DocImpact

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api

Change-Id: I8cdf52be0c8b19f7704848029a78373da8018cab

commit_message:
Set raw image size to be multiple of 64k

This works around a bug in qemu-img causing it to sometimes error if
compressing a raw image that isn't a multiple of 64k (the qcow2
cluster size).
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/1180021
http://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/qemu-devel/2013-04/msg02520.html

Change-Id: I88f8bb5c6bf3606ef5856b085a284af6b8858dbb

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary sleeps

These sleeps are no longer required as they can be replaced with a more
targeted search to wait for Free VCPU's to be reported.

Also increase how long we wait for the overcloud to come up as it is
currently quite close.

Change-Id: I72176e653cab85f26e3ed1f9998ff66e2de473b9

subject: Do not check free_ram_mb when doing live migration
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 782, 'name': 'John Garbutt', 'email': 'john@johngarbutt.com', 'username': 'johngarbutt'}, {'_account_id': 1501, 'name': 'Phil Day', 'email': 'philip.day@hp.com', 'username': 'philip-day'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 1653, 'name': 'garyk', 'email': 'gkotton@vmware.com', 'username': 'garyk'}, {'_account_id': 1970, 'name': 'Jacob Wen', 'email': 'wenjianhn@gmail.com', 'username': 'wenjianhn'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2271, 'name': 'Michael Still', 'email': 'mikal@stillhq.com', 'username': 'mikalstill'}, {'_account_id': 2667, 'name': 'Alex Glikson', 'email': 'glikson@il.ibm.com', 'username': 'glikson'}, {'_account_id': 2835, 'name': 'Brian Elliott', 'email': 'bdelliott@gmail.com', 'username': 'belliott'}, {'_account_id': 4190, 'name': 'lifeless', 'email': 'robertc@robertcollins.net', 'username': 'lifeless'}, {'_account_id': 6929, 'name': 'XiaoLiang Hu', 'email': 'xlhuxa@cn.ibm.com', 'username': 'xlhuxa'}, {'_account_id': 7494, 'name': 'Guangya Liu', 'email': 'gyliu513@gmail.com', 'username': 'JayLau'}, {'_account_id': 8495, 'name': 'Jake Liu', 'email': 'jake@unitedstack.com', 'username': 'JakeLiu'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-08-22 01:22:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't think removing the check is appropriate; live migration and scheduler decisions should be in sync with each other, and this makes them be out of sync : a cloud configured for no over-commit could end up overcommitted this way, couldn't it?

Surely the right thing to do is to ask the scheduler if the live migration is ok, and if it is doit - that would avoid repeated checks."}, {'account_id': 7494, 'date': '2013-08-22 09:30:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@John, please show your comments if any.

In my understanding, we should leave the memory checking to nova compute as some hypervisors support resource over commit natively, also nova scheduler RamFilter should handle the memory checking. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 8495, 'date': '2013-08-22 11:49:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks lifeless and Jay Lau for your review comments, I also prefer that we not do the memory checking for live migration. As by default, nova is using RamFilter with ram_allocation_ratio as 1.5. Add memory checking in nova conductor for RamFilter might make the logic between nova conductor and nova scheduler not clear.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-08-22 14:00:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

So I agree in theory that we the ram check should be removed from conductor, but I agree with lifeless that the scheduler should be consulted.

It is the scheduler's job to make policy decisions about memory allocation and the like.  The compute has logic to protect its own resources, but the overcommit policies are passed in filter properties from scheduler.  

I suggest you rebase your patch onto John's and add logic to check with scheduler if the provided destination is consistent with policy:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30868/"}, {'account_id': 8495, 'date': '2013-08-22 14:41:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks Brian for the comments. In my understanding, I think that nova conductor already consult nova scheduler for destination host as it need to call scheduler.driver.select_hosts to select the right target host. The reason we got this issue is that with RamFilter, if we configured ram_allocation_ratio as a value greater than 1 then we may run into this problem: scheduler think the memory resource is enough but nova conductor think resource is not enough. So I propose that we remove the memory checking in nova conductor.

Also just noticed that you have approved John's patch, so what about keep my current my patch as a separate one with John's?"}, {'account_id': 8495, 'date': '2013-08-23 14:16:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@John, @Brian and @lifeless, any comments? Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 7494, 'date': '2013-08-26 15:03:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-08-26 15:22:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Jake - It looks like the free ram check in the conductor is only done if destination is not None.  

Where is the scheduler checking the ram in this case?  I don't believe it is.  I agree that the check should be removed from conductor, but then shouldn't scheduler manage the overcommit policy?"}, {'account_id': 8495, 'date': '2013-08-26 15:35:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks Brian. The issue that you mentioned is being handled in another patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/36087/25/nova/conductor/tasks/live_migrate.py

What about merge this first and leave https://review.openstack.org/#/c/36087 to handle the issue as you mentioned.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-08-26 16:36:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Jake - Looks like 36807 is abandoned. :)'}, {'account_id': 8495, 'date': '2013-08-26 23:32:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yes, it was abandoned due to not active for two weeks. But I think that what your proposal does deserve a new patch. ;-)

What about handle this patch first and then handle the scheduler part? Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-08-28 13:55:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

This code was present in the scheduler driver in Folsom, its not new in Havana.

This code has been moved from the scheduler because its complexity that is "task specific", and moved to the generic "select_hosts" call.

I think the better question, is how should this check be done? I think we can probably remove the check, because the scheduler method we call should take all this into account:
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/scheduler/manager.py#L284'}, {'account_id': 8495, 'date': '2013-08-28 14:12:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Thanks John! So you agree with my fix except the commit log?'}, {'account_id': 8495, 'date': '2013-08-28 14:26:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-08-28 14:27:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-28 15:15:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- gate-nova-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/13/43213/2/check/gate-nova-pep8/796ff80 : SUCCESS in 9m 04s
- gate-nova-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/13/43213/2/check/gate-nova-docs/fe5bd04/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 8m 41s
- gate-nova-python26 http://logs.openstack.org/13/43213/2/check/gate-nova-python26/59c5b9d : SUCCESS in 22m 32s
- gate-nova-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/13/43213/2/check/gate-nova-python27/584f878 : SUCCESS in 16m 53s
- gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full http://logs.openstack.org/13/43213/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/64da288 : SUCCESS in 22m 50s
- gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full http://logs.openstack.org/13/43213/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/bf1ebff : SUCCESS in 21m 34s
- gate-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron http://logs.openstack.org/13/43213/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron/39d72b8 : SUCCESS in 15m 10s

- gate-nova-pylint http://logs.openstack.org/13/43213/2/check/gate-nova-pylint/1296eed : SUCCESS in 16m 27s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 7494, 'date': '2013-09-01 08:53:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks Jake!'}, {'account_id': 1970, 'date': '2013-09-02 03:40:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Why not migrate the instance to another host?
I don't think migrating/booting an instance to/on a host with high memory usage is a good practice.

The cost of doing live migration first and rolling back live migration later is high.

I think we need to keep the check."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-09-02 06:45:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hi,
I agree. I think an issue like this should maybe be discussed on the mail list.
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 8495, 'date': '2013-09-02 12:03:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks Jian and Gary for the comments. But the logic is not migrating/booting an instance to/on a host with high memory usage but select host based on scheduler filters. You can take a look at https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/conductor/tasks/live_migrate.py#L179, select_hosts will help live migration select a host based on scheduler filters.'}, {'account_id': 2667, 'date': '2013-09-03 07:25:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I tend to agree with Jake that this check conflicts with the scheduler, and should be removed.'}, {'account_id': 7494, 'date': '2013-09-03 07:46:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This might become a block issue for live migration with resource over commit features (RamFilter&CoreFilter).

So Agree with Alex and Jake, we should remove the checking and make nova scheduler as the decision maker for this.

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-09-03 08:33:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 6929, 'date': '2013-09-03 08:58:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-09-03 16:08:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Removing the check seems wrong to me. This could lead to lots of annoying issues on the target host. For example the live migration could work perfectly, but then cause a whole bunch of swapping.

It appears that the check is done using ram_allocation_ratio during the scheduling portion, but what if live_migrate is called while specifying a destination host? It seems to me that the call should fail if there isn't enough ram there."}, {'account_id': 8495, 'date': '2013-09-03 16:21:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Vish, thanks for your comments! 

For your question 1), it depends on if customer RamFIlter and ram allocation ratio. If RamFilter was enabled and the value was great than 1, then there might be some swapping on hypervisor host; But if did not use RamFilter or set ram allocation as 1, then no swapping issue. In one word, the swapping issue depends on Admin configuration, I think we can leave this to Admin.

For question 2), when live migration failed for such case, nova compute will rollback live migration and set the VM back to active. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-09-03 16:50:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I don't really like depending on rollback to handle the second case if we can fail on the initial request."}, {'account_id': 2667, 'date': '2013-09-03 17:19:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

@Vish: keeping this check would enable a situation when provisioning of a new VM on host X would succeed, while migration of a VM of the same flavor to X would fail.. don't you think this needs to be fixed?"}, {'account_id': 1970, 'date': '2013-09-03 17:47:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

In the bug report, an destination host selected by admin was used. In this case, the scheduler doesn't select a host for live migration. How does this patch fixes the bug with a different logic? 

I don't think we need to fix the bug.
If the memory usage of a selected destination is high, generally we should not migrate any instance to it. 
Check the available memory, let it *fail fast* to lower the cost. This is a good strategy in a cloud enviroment. Rollback live migration should be triggered under more unexpected exceptions."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-09-03 20:37:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Alex: yes i think it needs to be fixed, I just think it should be fixed by using the same logic in both cases (i.e. taking ram oversubscription into account) rather than ignoring the check. It seems clear that this check is done in the scheduler when the migration is selecting the host but I think removing it means the check is skipped if we migrate to a specific host.'}, {'account_id': 8495, 'date': '2013-09-03 23:16:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Vish & @Jian, Brian already mentioned the issue that you pointed out.

There is another patch handling this: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/36087/25/nova/conductor/tasks/live_migrate.py, but the patch was somewhat abandoned because not active recently. This patch might need more discussion to come to a conclusion.

What about merge this first and leave https://review.openstack.org/#/c/36087 to handle the issue of "scheduler check target host specified by admin when live migration"? Thanks for your understanding.

-- Jake'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-09-04 15:28:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 8495, 'date': '2013-09-06 13:36:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Wow, three -1 and three +1, thanks all for your voting. ;-)

I think that now the main concern is that for migration with target host, we need the checking, I agree with this point. But for now, I think that we can remove the checking as I think for most case, we should let nova scheduler make the decision to decide where to migrate the VM.

Also I think that in I version, we probably make some enhancement for conductor to check scheduler hint when migrate VM no matter with target host or not.

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-09-06 17:28:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Why can't we just make it an option to the live migrate command that when a host is specified the admin gets the choice of whether to have the memory check or not ?

We seem to be trying to second guess what the admin has in mind, and will only every be right 50% of the time (as shown by the split in votes ;-)"}, {'account_id': 8495, 'date': '2013-09-10 16:13:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks Phil, agree with you. Just upload a new patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/45900/ with your proposal, please help take a look.'}, {'account_id': 8495, 'date': '2013-09-10 16:13:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

Please refer to the new patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/45900/

Thanks.'}]

commit_message:
Do not check free_ram_mb when doing live migration

There is no need to check memory for live migration, since if live
migration failed, nova compute will rollback the live migration
operation.

Also some hypervisors does support resource overcommit natively
such as KVM and VMWare, we can remove the memory checking and let
nova compute handle this case.

Fix bug 1214943

Change-Id: I4c9fd0321c6f1559d6d702394e6191ff4c61e014

[{'created': '2013-09-09 18:57:26.000000000', 'message': 'Lower Heat max_template_size for Tempest

The default size leaves a very large padding for users to create larger
templates, but for testing and development a 10kB template is plenty.

This value is specifically meant to mirror upcoming changes to tempest
so that they are unified and can be tested in lock-step.

Change-Id: I0ea9798018a6d864ac04429c3ac89fb374583fb6
'}]
commit_message:
Lower Heat max_template_size for Tempest

The default size leaves a very large padding for users to create larger
templates, but for testing and development a 10kB template is plenty.

This value is specifically meant to mirror upcoming changes to tempest
so that they are unified and can be tested in lock-step.

Change-Id: I0ea9798018a6d864ac04429c3ac89fb374583fb6

commit_message:
Modify midonet plugin to support the latest MidoNet

MidoNet has been upgraded and devstack needs to be updated to
be compatible.  This change is required to run the current
version of MidoNet plugin with DevStack.

Closes-Bug: #1222314
Change-Id: If3379b4d5da4e4fcf989ee7398b5952d71b68d5a
