commit_message:
Make install_venv.py executable.

Not sure why this script was not executable before.

Since it is to be used as an executable, add a shebang line
and chmod it +x.

Change-Id: Idb59b53c7ffeec96b49ecd8132c6469861adc143

commit_message:
Merge with Oslo (2548344)

Merge utils with current master (2548344)
from Oslo-incubator.

This brings, along other fixes, a lot of Hacking
related warning improvements that block cinder
from enabling gating on hacking related checks.

The list of commits included in this merge are:

    0bf03b7  Add network_utils.urlsplit
    15c17fb  Make lock_file_prefix optional
    1a2df89  Enable H302 hacking check
    1b076ed  Ensure install_venv works behind firewalls
    1dcc747  Fix stylistic problems with help text
    22ec8ff  Make AMQP based RPC consumer threads more robust
    27d4b41  Move synchronized body to a first-class function
    323e465  Add conditional exception reraise
    3243cdf  python3: handle module moves in log
    3948aee  Highlighting the deprecated nature of 'log-format'.
    67bd769  python3: Fix traceback while running python3
    7b7566b  Add netaddr.IPAddress support to to_primitive()
    8719d26  Don't attempt to patch eventlet without the patch
    90b6a65  Fix locking bug
    aa5b658  Allow passing a logging level to processutils.execute
    b21fc56  Fix bad default for show_deleted
    b41862d  Use param keyword for docstrings
    b873454  Added convenience APIs for lockutils
    c7c55b2  Improve usability when backdoor_port is nonzero
    cb2a2b6  Modify local.py to not be dependent on Eventlet
    d28fa69  python3: Add python3 compatibility.
    df3f2ba  BaseException.message is deprecated since Python 2.6
    e456727  Remove useless logging in networks_utils

Change-Id: I5af3be85cc97bf7cb3968cd544460df9e3fb9ca7

[{'created': '2013-09-06 02:04:05.000000000', 'message': 'Use the lock decorator and close/join the thread pool

When the thread pool is owned by the engine (when it
is not passed in) we should be careful and ensure that
we close the engine (this stops it from accepting new
work) and then join the engine (this ensures that all
contained threads complete) to resource leakage.

Change-Id: Icb6e0f8051c017458657b4ff8872d3af44565c18
Fixes: bug 1221382

commit_message:
Use the lock decorator and close/join the thread pool

When the thread pool is owned by the engine (when it
is not passed in) we should be careful and ensure that
we close the pool (this stops it from accepting new
work) and then join on the pool (this ensures that all
contained threads complete) to avoid resource leakage.

Change-Id: Icb6e0f8051c017458657b4ff8872d3af44565c18
Fixes: bug 1221382

commit_message:
Fix error casting value to float in lvm.py

Special locale setting may result in that "vgs" command output different
results. Such as:

$ LC_NUMERIC='es_ES.UTF-8' sudo vgs
VG #PV #LV #SN Attr VSize VFree
vg_eharney 1 6 1 wz--n- 465,25g 12,97g

Fix bug 1219963

Change-Id: Ibe79d5ce673738d8e37f86de9106ab347c21bd52

commit_message:
Move dbinstance into a TemplateResource

The old dbinstance will soon be overtaken by the trove resource.
- The only reason for keeping this around is for people that don't
  have trove installed and want to use the AWS resource.
- Seperating it out into a TemplateResource really makes it easier
  for deployers and users to customise it.
- The old dbinstance did nothing "special" in python, and was really
  one of the first "TemplateResources" as it attempted to convert properties
  into parameters. Since this in now done a lot better in the TemplateResource
  lets just make use of that.

This will make it easier to migrate to other distros and versions.

Partial-Bug: #1215797
Change-Id: If72e1f40f67dc831551e0db8df8caaa002aaaeda

commit_message:
Make global TemplateResources usable in the tests

At the moment we need the templates installed into /etc/heat/templates
and this is not very nice for the tests. So this patch
replaces "/etc/heat/templates" with the project's own template
path so we can at least test the api of the template resources.

Partial-Bug: #1215797
Change-Id: Ie4924b0358b97af8feaad93ed9187976b8932e3d

commit_message:
Make the new template validation usable from tests

This is so we can assert that new TemplateResources expose the
api that we are expecting.

Partial-Bug: #1215797
Change-Id: I6273f6e046bb7bd5e075e9190d8011af976573b8

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-06 20:14:35.000000000', 'message': 'Prevents 400 NVP errors caused by a None display_name

The API forbids a resource name to be None, but the
Model does not. Such errors may  be induced by
programming directly against the plugin interface. With
this fix we avoid raising 400 faults which may be introduced
by involuntary programming errors.

Fixes bug 1221896

Change-Id: Ic1201c5af5691f2bed38753453f73c229858b10f
'}, {'created': '2013-09-06 20:59:34.000000000', 'message': 'Prevents 400 NVP errors caused by a None display_name

The API forbids a resource name to be None, but the
Model does not. Such errors may  be induced by
programming directly against the plugin interface. With
this fix we avoid raising 400 faults which may be introduced
by involuntary programming errors.

Fixes bug 1221896

Change-Id: Ic1201c5af5691f2bed38753453f73c229858b10f
'}]
commit_message:
Prevents 400 NVP errors caused by a None display_name

The API forbids a resource name to be None, but the
Model does not. Such errors may  be induced by
programming directly against the plugin interface. With
this fix we avoid raising 400 faults which may be introduced
by involuntary programming errors.

Fixes bug 1221896

Change-Id: Ic1201c5af5691f2bed38753453f73c229858b10f

commit_message:
Load ML2 TypeDrivers in named order.

Similar to another bug on the MechanismDriver front, we need to specify the
stevedor parameter to load drivers in named order for ML2 TypeDrivers.

Fixes bug 1221781

Change-Id: Iacddf4c912bc5629172da7aaf9077e809a35e065

[{'created': '2013-08-25 06:18:05.000000000', 'message': 'Allow uuid specification

When adding allow the api to
take in the uuid of the runner
to be added, which maybe the
task uuid or a other uuid. If

will generate (and return) a
new uuid.

Change-Id: I1634f76b04ab798d2902165d9845597618da92d7
'}, {'created': '2013-08-26 17:57:29.000000000', 'message': 'Allow uuid specification

When adding allow the api to take in the uuid
of the runner to be added, which maybe the task
uuid or another uuid. If not provided then the
runner will generate (and return) a new uuid.

This is useful to be able to tie into the resuming
system which goes by uuids, if the runner uuid is
different from the task uuid (which is acceptable
if the same task is added twice) then it becomes
hard to resume a dynamically changing uuid. This
change allows manual connection of the runner uuid
to the task which will ease resuming until we fix
how flows need to be able to save there runners
uuids (and structure).

Change-Id: I1634f76b04ab798d2902165d9845597618da92d7
'}]
commit_message:
Allow uuid specification

When adding allow the api to take in the uuid
of the runner to be added, which maybe the task
uuid or another uuid. If not provided then the
runner will generate (and return) a new uuid.

This is useful to be able to tie into the resuming
system which goes by uuids, if the runner uuid is
different from the task uuid (which is acceptable
if the same task is added twice) then it becomes
hard to resume a dynamically changing uuid. This
change allows manual connection of the runner uuid
to the task which will ease resuming until we fix
how flows need to be able to save there runners
uuids (and structure).

Change-Id: I1634f76b04ab798d2902165d9845597618da92d7

commit_message:
Add a delete() method to DiskFile

In preparation for making the DiskFile class an abstraction layer for
the backend to all the object server REST API services, we add a
simple delete method which encapsulates the required behavior.

Change-Id: I539ad53c297e4c572e2f93c2524188fb89b2db40
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix output of tools/validate.py --force

Previously:
Validation of all files and build of all books will be forced.

Following files will be validated:
>>> doc/src/docbkx/basic-install/src/basic-install_compute-common.xml
>>> doc/src/docbkx/basic-install/src/basic-install_controller-dashboard.xml
>>> doc/src/docbkx/basic-install/src/basic-install_controller-keystone.xml
>>> doc/src/docbkx/basic-install/src/basic-install_controller-neutron.xml
>>> doc/src/docbkx/basic-install/src/basic-install_controller-nova.xml
...

But that information is wrong since all files will get validated. Now
you get:
Validation of all files and build of all books will be forced.

Validating all files
file admin-guide-cloud/ch_networking.xml:
...

Change-Id: If07544f532bd6861a23f52aa7fda044d0673cccc

files to match Havana usage. Changed <computeroutput> tags to
<programlisting> or <userinput>, where needed.

commit_message:
Eliminate the impact of "wait_until='BUILD'"

BUILD is just a middle state within a short period of time.
It's suspended and unstable when creating a server,
and it will be ACTIVE eventually if everything is ok.

But many places uses the wait_until='BUILD' to create server.
resp, server = cls.create_server(image_id=cls.image_ref,
                                   flavor=cls.flavor_ref,
                                   wait_until='BUILD')

In this patch I add following code in wait_for_server_status
method instead of deleting those incorrect usage.
Thus will use the smallest change
to support BUILD state for wait_until as well.

if status == 'BUILD' and server_status != 'UNKNOWN':
            return

Change-Id: I146fdff56af29ae0aef9b5cff8bcea5468ff595c
Closes-Bug: #1214202

[{'created': '2013-09-06 16:55:07.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Call safe_encode() instead of str()"

This reverts commit df44a7e25d47329fd863a5830b053c1cc3a0251f.

Not only did it not account for the object versioning changes
required, or all the other string attributes we have, but the
unicode "fix" was backwards anyway (we should be decoding, not
encoding there).

Change-Id: I2369a79944fa5cb3b076e09a92f5075ec3427f46
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Call safe_encode() instead of str()"

This reverts commit df44a7e25d47329fd863a5830b053c1cc3a0251f.

Not only did it not account for the object versioning changes
required, or all the other string attributes we have, but the
unicode "fix" was backwards anyway (we should be decoding, not
encoding there).

Change-Id: I2369a79944fa5cb3b076e09a92f5075ec3427f46

commit_message:
Fix Neutron issues related to Baremetal service

When deploying devstack on a single host with a single NIC and
baremetal and neutron services enabled, the host looses Internet
access as default route is deleted.

Also, if localrc is not correctly set with correct values, OVS ports
and Neutron net and subnet aren't created (commands missing
arguments), we need devstack to properly fail.

Change-Id: I7f39bbdf7b8cb544b8b4a59effe16f04b85d1425

commit_message:
Remove test string from translation files

Closes-Bug: #1221123

Removing unnecessary translation strings reduces translation work.
String Freeze is enabled so this patch also update en PO files.

Change-Id: Ie69c8d0b990e53678262457094852b1ef4966b8b

commit_message:
NFS section for block storage Nexenta driver

1. Add table with list of options to iSCSI section of Nexenta volume
driver.
2. Add NFS section for Openstack Block Storage Nexenta volume driver.

Change-Id: I4f0bd0d2edd72b4aae1121a8334917980f267f56

Thierry, we're talking about merging this patch into the Havana release. The risk is very low since the default value of this configuration option doesn't change nova's behavior at all. The reward is high since it makes eliminating a big bottleneck in typical openstack deployments very simple (e.g., setting workers=10)."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-09-05 20:31:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

'}, {'account_id': 5600, 'date': '2013-09-05 22:21:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Indeed, we've got very strong feelings about this getting into Havana either as a fix or being granted a feature exception.

Given that conductor an RPC-to-DB access layer on top of a DB that can't perform nearly as well as most production level DBs can be tuned, and given that the patch is provided to address eventlet and single-threaded library behavior for the reference DB backend, I think it's much more of a fix than a new feature.

Not to mention this patch takes the unofficial community-based workarounds out of the picture and provides a real solution--a simple one at that, thanks to Peter's work on this and the performance measuring he's done.

If there's anything we can do to support this getting into Havana, particularly in the feature freeze exception process, by all means give me a shout! :)"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-09-05 22:47:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

preaching to the choir.  There is something to do, ask the ML for a FFE see http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-September/014656.html for details'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2013-09-06 08:10:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@peter: sounds pretty reasonable. Please post to the ML (as suggested above) so that Russell and I can discuss it.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-09-06 16:36:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-16 13:23:12.000000000', 'message': "add conf for number of conductor workers

Fixes bug #1213080.

Make it easy to launch a bunch of conductor processes on a host.

Deploying multiple conductor workers per host avoids serialization on
database accesses caused by libmysqlclient.so blocking eventlet's
single thread. In an experiment on a 24-core machine, when creating 20
VMs in parallel, maximum creation time was reduced by approx. 10s when
using 20 conductor processes vis-a-vis a single conductor process.
Profiling showed that all of the savings came from faster calls into
nova.db.sqlalchemy.api.

Note that there are alternative methods for preventing the eventlet
thread from blocking during database calls. However, none of these
alternatives performed as well as multiple nova-conductor processes.

    * Instead of using the native database driver like _mysql.so, you
      can use a pure-python driver, like pymysql by setting
      sql_connection=mysql+pymysql://... in the [DEFAULT] section of
      /etc/nova/nova.conf, which eventlet will monkeypatch to avoid
      blocking. The problem with this approach is the vastly greater
      CPU demand of the pure-python driver compared to the native
      driver. Since the pure-python driver is so much more CPU
      intensive, the eventlet thread spends most of its time talking to
      the database, which effectively the problem we had before!

    * Instead of making database calls from eventletâs thread, you can
      submit them to eventletâs pool of worker threads and wait for the
      results. Try this by setting dbapi_use_tpool=True in the
      [DEFAULT] section of /etc/nova/nova.conf.  The problem I found
      with this approach was the overhead of synchronizing with the
      worker threads. In particular, the time elapsed between the
      worker thread finishing and the waiting coroutine being resumed
      was typically several times greater than the duration of the
      database call itself.

Change-Id: I8698997d211d7617ee14a1c6113056a694d70620
"}, {'created': '2013-08-19 18:21:11.000000000', 'message': "add conf for number of conductor workers

Profiling showed that all of the savings came from faster calls into
nova.db.sqlalchemy.api.

Note that there are alternative methods for preventing the eventlet
thread from blocking during database calls. However, none of these
alternatives performed as well as multiple nova-conductor processes.

    * Instead of using the native database driver like _mysql.so, you

    * Instead of making database calls from eventletâs thread, you can
      submit them to eventletâs pool of worker threads and wait for the
      results. Try this by setting dbapi_use_tpool=True in the
      [DEFAULT] section of /etc/nova/nova.conf.  The problem I found
      with this approach was the overhead of synchronizing with the

      with this approach was the overhead of synchronizing with the
      worker threads. In particular, the time elapsed between the
      worker thread finishing and the waiting coroutine being resumed
      was typically several times greater than the duration of the
      database call itself.

Change-Id: I8698997d211d7617ee14a1c6113056a694d70620
"}, {'created': '2013-09-05 20:08:52.000000000', 'message': "add conf for number of conductor workers

Fixes bug #1213080 and implements blueprint condutor-workers.

Make it easy to launch a bunch of conductor processes on a host.

Deploying multiple conductor workers per host avoids serialization on
database accesses caused by libmysqlclient.so blocking eventlet's
single thread. In an experiment on a 24-core machine, when creating 20
VMs in parallel, maximum creation time was reduced by approx. 10s when
using 20 conductor processes vis-a-vis a single conductor process.
Profiling showed that all of the savings came from faster calls into
nova.db.sqlalchemy.api.

Note that there are alternative methods for preventing the eventlet
thread from blocking during database calls. However, none of these
alternatives performed as well as multiple nova-conductor processes.

    * Instead of using the native database driver like _mysql.so, you
      can use a pure-python driver, like pymysql by setting
      sql_connection=mysql+pymysql://... in the [DEFAULT] section of
      /etc/nova/nova.conf, which eventlet will monkeypatch to avoid
      blocking. The problem with this approach is the vastly greater
      CPU demand of the pure-python driver compared to the native
      driver. Since the pure-python driver is so much more CPU
      intensive, the eventlet thread spends most of its time talking to
      the database, which effectively the problem we had before!

    * Instead of making database calls from eventletâs thread, you can
      submit them to eventletâs pool of worker threads and wait for the
      results. Try this by setting dbapi_use_tpool=True in the
      [DEFAULT] section of /etc/nova/nova.conf.  The problem I found
      with this approach was the overhead of synchronizing with the
      worker threads. In particular, the time elapsed between the
      worker thread finishing and the waiting coroutine being resumed
      was typically several times greater than the duration of the
      database call itself.

Change-Id: I8698997d211d7617ee14a1c6113056a694d70620
"}]
commit_message:
add conf for number of conductor workers

Fixes bug #1213080 and implements blueprint condutor-workers.

Make it easy to launch a bunch of conductor processes on a host.

Deploying multiple conductor workers per host avoids serialization on
database accesses caused by libmysqlclient.so blocking eventlet's
single thread. In an experiment on a 24-core machine, when creating 20
VMs in parallel, maximum creation time was reduced by approx. 10s when
using 20 conductor processes vis-a-vis a single conductor process.
Profiling showed that all of the savings came from faster calls into
nova.db.sqlalchemy.api.

Note that there are alternative methods for preventing the eventlet
thread from blocking during database calls. However, none of these
alternatives performed as well as multiple nova-conductor processes.

    * Instead of using the native database driver like _mysql.so, you
      can use a pure-python driver, like pymysql by setting
      sql_connection=mysql+pymysql://... in the [DEFAULT] section of
      /etc/nova/nova.conf, which eventlet will monkeypatch to avoid
      blocking. The problem with this approach is the vastly greater
      CPU demand of the pure-python driver compared to the native
      driver. Since the pure-python driver is so much more CPU
      intensive, the eventlet thread spends most of its time talking to
      the database, which effectively the problem we had before!

    * Instead of making database calls from eventletâs thread, you can
      submit them to eventletâs pool of worker threads and wait for the
      results. Try this by setting dbapi_use_tpool=True in the
      [DEFAULT] section of /etc/nova/nova.conf.  The problem I found
      with this approach was the overhead of synchronizing with the
      worker threads. In particular, the time elapsed between the
      worker thread finishing and the waiting coroutine being resumed
      was typically several times greater than the duration of the
      database call itself.

Change-Id: I8698997d211d7617ee14a1c6113056a694d70620

commit_message:
Removes openstack-object-storage-admin directory, moving content.

Moves config info to Config Ref
Moves Admin CLI task to Admin User Guide
Moves CLI tasks to User Guide
Moves Monitoring section to Cloud Admin Guide
Removes anything that was a copy/paste from dev docs completely, refers
to developer docs instead

Closes-bug: 1216037

commit_message:
Avoid errors on some actions when image not usable

Using the metadata saved on instance creation, we can now get all the
image related metadata we need from the instance itself.

This patch replace the logic for getting the image metadata on some
actions that shouldn't fail when the image is not accessible (create
an snapshot, resize, migrate, rescue an instance or attach an
interface).

Fixes bug 1039662

Change-Id: Id8c2f13ca96908317d271a84fd685104b64f87e9

subject: Add methods to get image metadata from instance

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-26 21:23:42.000000000', 'message': "Add methods to get image metadata from instance

This patch adds a couple of utility functions that enclose all the logic
for getting and parsing the image metadata stored in the instance's
system metadata.

First, this will try to fetch the metadata from the real image and will
prevent it from failing if it is not available. It will be then merged
with the image metadata stored during the instance creation.

Related to bug #1039662

Change-Id: I2130caf19858585571b1199e27f0a98ad5f08701

prevent it from failing if it is not available. It will be then merged
with the image metadata stored during the instance creation.

Related to bug #1039662

Change-Id: I2130caf19858585571b1199e27f0a98ad5f08701
"}]
commit_message:
Add methods to get image metadata from instance

This patch adds a couple of utility functions that enclose all the logic
for getting and parsing the image metadata stored in the instance's
system metadata.

First, this will try to fetch the metadata from the real image and will
prevent it from failing if it is not available. It will be then merged
with the image metadata stored during the instance creation.

Related to bug #1039662

Change-Id: I2130caf19858585571b1199e27f0a98ad5f08701

commit_message:
Rename ceilometer alarm service name

Rename service name "ceilometer-alarm-eval" to
"ceilometer-alarm-singleton" and "ceilometer-alarm-notify" to
ceilometer-alarm-notifier" in this patch.

Change-Id: I6619cc02874f6f59c43ba2952325e9d0533e395d

commit_message:
Trusts for longrunning tasks:
 * Create trusts from current user to savanna user when cluster is created
 * Auth savanna user with trust
 * use savanna user with trust for nova and cinder, when cluster is deleted

Change-Id: Ic134dc9200dcf1b424b5e7ccabd72a1a029c696e

commit_message:
Replace assertEquals with assertEqual

The method assertEquals has been deprecated since python 2.7.
http://docs.python.org/2/library/unittest.html#deprecated-aliases

Also in Python 3, a deprecated warning is raised when using assertEquals
therefore we should use assertEqual instead.

Fixes bug #1221601

Change-Id: Id502cfbc210c6c3fe0a256d5350e159ffa220141

[{'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-09-06 13:01:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Could you clarify, why loading order is important?'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2013-09-06 13:13:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 6694, 'date': '2013-09-06 13:14:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@enikanorov - It was the design intent that these mechanism drivers are called in the order listed from the ini file. 
I was actually looking to fix another issue when I noticed the mech drivers weren't ordered as listed. The fix was so trivial that I decided to create this bug.

Here's the IRC from June 12, 2013:

15:11:20 <apech_> yeah, i guess the other one that comes up (outside of the specific API), is how to order mechanism driver calls
15:11:46 <apech_> so if you enable two mechanism drivers, do we need to be able to specify the order in which they are called? is it registration order?
15:12:20 <mestery> Registration order would be easiest I guess, and would enable the user to order things, for better or worse.
15:12:25 <rkukura> apech_: ordering is something I've been thinking about for the ml2-portbinding DP
15:12:34 <rcurran> i guess i envisioned an ini file having the list of mech_drivers ... called in that order
15:12:54 <rkukura> We want to be able to prioritize which mechanism to try first, ...
15:13:08 <mestery> rkukura: So something like what rcurran suggested here?
15:13:17 <rcurran> and the order configured in the ini isn't good enough
15:13:19 <Sukhdev> How do you decide on the priority?
15:13:47 <mestery> Sukhdev: Order in the .ini file?
15:14:01 <rkukura> probably - but I'd want to look at stevedore again to see if the same mechanism_driver list can be used once they are loaded"}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-09-06 13:16:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Load ML2 mech drivers as listed in ml2_conf.ini

stevedore requires an additional parameter to be used (name_order=True) to
sort the loaded extensions to match the order used in the parameter "names".

bug 1221490

Change-Id: I614716c45d91cdf152650fba5ec8ced1e9c5aad4

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-05 18:32:37.000000000', 'message': 'fix(storage.mongodb): Race condition when creating a claim

This patch forces MessageController.claimed to always query the primary in
order to resolve a race condition in ClaimController.create. The latter
method tags a batch of messages with a claim ID, then immediately
calles claimed() to get a list of messages that were actually updated.

MessageController.claimed is also used by ClaimController.update, so that
request will no longer read from secondaries either. This shouldn't put
much more load on the primary, and may even be desired behavior in the case
that a client creates a claim and immediately attempts to update it, in
which case they could get a "not found" if the new claim hasn't propagated
yet to the secondary being queried.

Change-Id: I8b5cfee1cc6f185ebf53e98fad95a5fc30e021da
Partial-Bug: #1218990
'}]
commit_message:
fix(storage.mongodb): Race condition when creating a claim

This patch forces MessageController.claimed to always query the primary in
order to resolve a race condition in ClaimController.create. The latter
method tags a batch of messages with a claim ID, then immediately
calles claimed() to get a list of messages that were actually updated.

MessageController.claimed is also used by ClaimController.update, so that
request will no longer read from secondaries either. This shouldn't put
much more load on the primary, and may even be desired behavior in the case
that a client creates a claim and immediately attempts to update it, in
which case they could get a "not found" if the new claim hasn't propagated
yet to the secondary being queried.

Change-Id: I8b5cfee1cc6f185ebf53e98fad95a5fc30e021da
Partial-Bug: #1218990

[{'created': '2013-09-06 04:14:10.000000000', 'message': "Fixes misuse of assertTrue in test scripts

Misuse of assertTrue in places where assertEqual should be used.

If assertTrue is used instead of assertEquals, the test will always pass
if the first argument's boolean cast is True. The second argument
passed to assertTrue() will be regarded as the error message
when the assertion fails. Using assertEqual will actually check
if two arguments are same value.

Fixes bug #1221517

Change-Id: I68f614164803729ea26e65f8868b0031e724d324
"}]
commit_message:
Fixes misuse of assertTrue in test scripts

Misuse of assertTrue in places where assertEqual should be used.

If assertTrue is used instead of assertEquals, the test will always pass
if the first argument's boolean cast is True. The second argument
passed to assertTrue() will be regarded as the error message
when the assertion fails. Using assertEqual will actually check
if two arguments are same value.

Fixes bug #1221517

Change-Id: I68f614164803729ea26e65f8868b0031e724d324

commit_message:
Fix wrong index in 10 migration for mysql

Errors was found in migration during testing of models with migrations
on different versions of different backends.
Bug consist in:
- for some of version in mysql we can get an error
"Specified key was too long; max key length is 1000 bytes".

bp: ceilometer-db-sync-models-with-migrations

Change-Id: I28c28fe94703d55d06696315e66de02597f17d83

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-06 13:18:18.000000000', 'message': 'Fix problem with long messages in Qpid (from oslo)

This is commit 478ac3a3e in oslo-incubator

Qpid has a limitation where it cannot serialize a dict containing a
string greater than 65535 characters. This change alters the Qpid
implementation to JSON encode the dict before sending it, but only if
Qpid would fail to serialize it. This maintains as much backward
compatibility as possible, though long messages will still fail if they
are sent to an older receiver.

Even though this change will modify the message format, it will only do
it when messages are longer than 65K which would be broken anyway and
could cause serious bugs like the one linked below.

Fixes bug 1215091

Change-Id: I2f0e88435748bab631d969573d3a598d9e1f7fef
'}]
commit_message:
Fix problem with long messages in Qpid (from oslo)

This is commit 478ac3a3e in oslo-incubator

Qpid has a limitation where it cannot serialize a dict containing a
string greater than 65535 characters. This change alters the Qpid
implementation to JSON encode the dict before sending it, but only if
Qpid would fail to serialize it. This maintains as much backward
compatibility as possible, though long messages will still fail if they
are sent to an older receiver.

Even though this change will modify the message format, it will only do
it when messages are longer than 65K which would be broken anyway and
could cause serious bugs like the one linked below.

Fixes bug 1215091

Change-Id: I2f0e88435748bab631d969573d3a598d9e1f7fef

'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-09-05 14:52:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

tempest allows to define 2 images, the instance password is an image related property,it should be defined for both images.

https://github.com/openstack-dev/devstack/blob/master/lib/tempest#L239 claims the ssh_user as instance user is deprecated.

image_ssh_user and the image_alt_ssh_user can be used, so if we ever want to use an instance password instead of a key (the instance validation should be ssh key based, but the change is not finished since long), we should define a password for the image.


 image_ssh_user
 image_ssh_password
 image_alt_ssh_user
 image_alt_ssh_password


'image_ssh_password' should be the password option for the first image.


(The ssh_user might be used for connecting to the compute/hyper-visor node in the future, and it may move to the whitebox section )"}, {'account_id': 8302, 'date': '2013-09-06 01:13:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-06 01:39:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

- image_alt_ssh_password
- volume_device_name

commit_message:
Add device name, ssh password to Tempest config

The following options have been added to the compute section of the
Tempest configuration:

- image_ssh_password
- image_alt_ssh_password
- volume_device_name

The "volume_device_name" is being added to rid the test_attach_volume
test of hardcoded data. In the effort to remove a hardcoded password
from the same test, we introduce the option "image_ssh_password" to
store the password instead. Then, the deprecated "ssh_user" in the
test is swapped out in favor of "image_ssh_user". Finally, we add an
"image_alt_ssh_password" so the option remains symmetrical to the
"image_ssh_password" option.

Closes-Bug: #1220514
Change-Id: If7816e534200c54826c1da0d0464f643163b8657

commit_message:
Remove wait for "Updating host status"

As of I749204d7d6461993d0c42bf5877b65c5ec17c62f this message is no
longer reported, testing suggests we no longer need to wait for it.
In fact it would appear the sleep statements after these lines are also
no longer required, I'll also remove these if further testing proves
this to be true.

Change-Id: I21af8f1c8b7803ccdb32a1de6654f84efc3c19cd

[{'created': '2013-08-20 19:10:46.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Add apiclient library"

This reverts commit 4b9b0139641f0e85805783d69dfc3650885cd24a.

Rationale: the apiclient library needs many fixes and updates that we
are not able to address at this time. In the future, we may consider
returning to using it, but for now, we will implement a base
connection module from which this client will be able to speak to
marconi servers.

Change-Id: I40b053e5487348f524753db517b79bf4ca81d569
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Add apiclient library"

This reverts commit 4b9b0139641f0e85805783d69dfc3650885cd24a.

Rationale: the apiclient library needs many fixes and updates that we
are not able to address at this time. In the future, we may consider
returning to using it, but for now, we will implement a base
connection module from which this client will be able to speak to
marconi servers.

Change-Id: I40b053e5487348f524753db517b79bf4ca81d569

commit_message:
Add Hive + MySQL configuration

 * Added MySQL config for Hive
 * Apply config if MySQL is enabled
 * Run MySQL if oozie and hive instances are not the same
 * Create Hive DB schema
 * Start metastore server

Partially implements blueprint edp-vanilla-plugin-hive-pig

Change-Id: I181bb8813091e8f61e8cba550363cd145c375e72

commit_message:
Add an ability to configure a job

Adds an ability to fulfil <configuration> block in workflow.xml
Partially implements blueprint edp-job-configs-params

Change-Id: I5c6dda92efc43aa4c56dd6b41b7b36bd94f4be5b

Add provider attribute to lb-pool-create command

Also add formatter for the provider attribute,
so if provider is empty or absent, it displayed as 'N/A'

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-03 00:45:09.000000000', 'message': "Make swift config tables the source of truth

As discussed on the mailing list, this patch will make the swift
configuration tables found in common a source of truth for the
helptext. The script that generates them has been updated for this,
and will now only add/remove options, update default values, and
replace helptext where it does not exist in the tables. Another
run of the script was done and tables were updated.

Backstory: All projects other than Swift use OpenStack Common for
configuration, and define option, default value and help text in the
code in a way that it's possible to extract.

Since the code is able to act in this way, we can stop maintaining
separate instructive lines for configuration options, and instead
fix any text problems in the code itself. This both improves the
quality of the code and fixes our double maintenance problem.

For swift, we needed a different approach. Unfortunately, I think we
don't have the ability to treat the code as the definitive source and
move all maintenance there. The lack of instruction for every option,
and absence of structure precludes this.

So I wrote some nasty scraping things (from RST and sample conf file)
to seed an initial list of configuration options.

My plan from here was to make the 'update' portion of the script
treat the textual descriptions in common/tables/swift-*.xml as
definitive.

The script would still search the swift code to add or remove
options, so we could guarantee completeness, and after an initial
push to write out proper help text the maintenance becomes far
simpler.

Change-Id: I2464f5c63cb0da110e1871a09a59380dad9b6b27
"}, {'created': '2013-09-04 17:19:27.000000000', 'message': "Make swift config tables the source of truth

commit_message:
Make swift config tables the source of truth

As discussed on the mailing list, this patch will make the swift
configuration tables found in common a source of truth for the
helptext. The script that generates them has been updated for this,
and will now only add/remove options, update default values, and
replace helptext where it does not exist in the tables. Another
run of the script was done and tables were updated.

Backstory: All projects other than Swift use OpenStack Common for
configuration, and define option, default value and help text in the
code in a way that it's possible to extract.

Since the code is able to act in this way, we can stop maintaining
separate instructive lines for configuration options, and instead
fix any text problems in the code itself. This both improves the
quality of the code and fixes our double maintenance problem.

For swift, we needed a different approach. Unfortunately, I think we
don't have the ability to treat the code as the definitive source and
move all maintenance there. The lack of instruction for every option,
and absence of structure precludes this.

So I wrote some nasty scraping things (from RST and sample conf file)
to seed an initial list of configuration options.

My plan from here was to make the 'update' portion of the script
treat the textual descriptions in common/tables/swift-*.xml as
definitive.

The script would still search the swift code to add or remove
options, so we could guarantee completeness, and after an initial
push to write out proper help text the maintenance becomes far
simpler.

Change-Id: I2464f5c63cb0da110e1871a09a59380dad9b6b27

commit_message:
Remove Social Integration buttons from Guides

pom.xml should not set socialIcons, otherwise the Facebook and
Twitter buttons are shown.

Change-Id: Id69cbcc5fe2fbd59f72dcbd884524424aa6d372f
Closes-Bug: #1221220

Oof, that's not fun.  I'm surprised that we can be hitting this in Folsom since we didn't use the envelope format there.  The console log must be doing something different that triggers the same behavior (I would look, but I'm not technically working this week so this is just a quick drive by comment before I take off on vacation).

Also, be aware that the fix for this in Grizzly was a compatibility-only fix.  If this is a problem there too then you'll need to provide the full fix in addition to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/31689/ ."}, {'account_id': 7808, 'date': '2013-09-02 16:09:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I thought that the issue was confirmed in folsom too but I probably misread some comment in LP because I can't find it... I'll change the review to WIP and try to reproduce it in folsom first.

The fix for Grizzly is here: https://review.openstack.org/44695"}, {'account_id': 7808, 'date': '2013-09-02 16:09:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-09-02 17:11:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Well, if we're seeing it in Grizzly then it could be in Folsom too because AFAIK the RPC change that triggered this other places didn't happen until Havana, so it would be a related but different problem.

I guess it wouldn't hurt to add this to Folsom either way.  If it doesn't hit the error condition in Qpid it will never use the new code, and if it does hit the error condition then it would have failed regardless so this is an improvement."}, {'account_id': 7808, 'date': '2013-09-03 09:36:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Ready For Review

[{'created': '2013-09-02 13:08:55.000000000', 'message': 'Fix problem with long messages in Qpid

Qpid has a limitation where it cannot serialize a dict containing a
string greater than 65535 characters. This change alters the Qpid
implementation to JSON encode the dict before sending it, but only if
Qpid would fail to serialize it. This maintains as much backward
compatibility as possible, though long messages will still fail if they
are sent to an older receiver.

Even though this change will modify the message format, it will only do
it when messages are longer than 65K which would be broken anyway and
could cause serious bugs like the one linked below.

Fixes bug 1215091

(cherry picked from commit 7ce54410485b33cffc39c7ffb96eae422b88601c)

commit_message:
Fix problem with long messages in Qpid

Qpid has a limitation where it cannot serialize a dict containing a
string greater than 65535 characters. This change alters the Qpid
implementation to JSON encode the dict before sending it, but only if
Qpid would fail to serialize it. This maintains as much backward
compatibility as possible, though long messages will still fail if they
are sent to an older receiver.

Even though this change will modify the message format, it will only do
it when messages are longer than 65K which would be broken anyway and
could cause serious bugs like the one linked below.

Fixes bug 1215091

(cherry picked from commit 7ce54410485b33cffc39c7ffb96eae422b88601c)

Conflicts:
	openstack/common/rpc/impl_qpid.py

Change-Id: I2f0e88435748bab631d969573d3a598d9e1f7fef

commit_message:
fix(transport.wsgi): JSON home doc missing GET and HEAD hints

GET and HEAD support was added for /v1/queues/{queue_name} but
the home document was not updated accordingly. This patch adds
those methods (AKA verbs) to the home document.

Change-Id: I82bbbf1b6d0735dc2d15faee715175fc724b9423

commit_message:
Added missing xml tests of volume

Volume test is only running for json
because some tests are missing in xml
Here added these missing tests in xml:-
*attach-volume
*detach-volume
*upload volume
added "xml" interface also for running the xml tests.

Also fixes: bug #1219779

Change-Id: Ifcb57f873c2522d2a2103d6adab2f4a9f53a39c8

commit_message:
Publish recent api changes as v2.2

Throughout the Havana development cycle, we have added several
features to the v2 api, without breaking backwards compatibility.
So this change bumps up our minor version number.

Change-Id: If0e5ffe117200fbfb967c8c95a63608f12dbba58
(cherry picked from commit 249f800de13867af31590df557a715cabbc2e1d6)

commit_message:
Sync English PO files with the latest code for Havana-3

Closes-Bug: #1221539

This commit updates English PO files only which requires for
translation. Other languages are not updated since they will
be update by importing translations from Transifex.

Change-Id: I126291ca5eb7c607b86446c2351062ce87600bbb

[{'created': '2013-09-06 09:25:00.000000000', 'message': "OSReactions: Use a category for OS planet

In order to manage posts publication frequency, we created a new
category under the which we'll publicizing posts meant to be read by
openstack's planet.

This category doesn't have any post yet, which makes this patch safe
since old posts won't be read again by the planet.

Change-Id: I662d3f3671dec72b817db99c733e3532975f12c1
"}]
commit_message:
OSReactions: Use a category for OS planet

In order to manage posts publication frequency, we created a new
category under the which we'll publicizing posts meant to be read by
openstack's planet.

This category doesn't have any post yet, which makes this patch safe
since old posts won't be read again by the planet.

Change-Id: I662d3f3671dec72b817db99c733e3532975f12c1

[{'created': '2013-09-06 07:21:42.000000000', 'message': 'Fix wrong migrations and fix tests in nova_notifier

This is a joint commit of 2 other commits from master:

For Postgres migrations are failed.
More then we can get for mysql an error
"Specified key was too long; max key length is 1000 bytes" in b6ae66d05e3
migration in some versions of dialect.
Fixes-Bug: #1219776
(cherry-picked from aae3f55304ff161b401b803769350e9cb66b0e8c)

The prototype for instance_update_and_get_original changed, so let's
ignore it completely for the future.
Fixes-Bug: #1221173
(cherry-picked from d2a87a9dfd3cd9ef034eed3d693683972c842576)

Change-Id: Id4d349bbc49cdc957076b3e211f70db9838cd4cb
'}]
commit_message:
Fix wrong migrations and fix tests in nova_notifier

This is a joint commit of 2 other commits from master:

For Postgres migrations are failed.
More then we can get for mysql an error
"Specified key was too long; max key length is 1000 bytes" in b6ae66d05e3
migration in some versions of dialect.
Fixes-Bug: #1219776
(cherry-picked from aae3f55304ff161b401b803769350e9cb66b0e8c)

The prototype for instance_update_and_get_original changed, so let's
ignore it completely for the future.
Fixes-Bug: #1221173
(cherry-picked from d2a87a9dfd3cd9ef034eed3d693683972c842576)

Change-Id: Id4d349bbc49cdc957076b3e211f70db9838cd4cb

commit_message:
Fix wrong migrations

For Postgres migrations are failed.
More then we can get for mysql an error
"Specified key was too long; max key length is 1000 bytes" in b6ae66d05e3
migration in some versions of dialect.

Fixes-Bug: #1219776
(cherry-picked from aae3f55304ff161b401b803769350e9cb66b0e8c)

Change-Id: Id9b0e1eb0e685053291367f7eb62fef68b6b2f84

commit_message:
nova_notifier: fix tests

The prototype for instance_update_and_get_original changed, so let's
ignore it completely for the future.

Fixes-Bug: #1221173
(cherry-picked from d2a87a9dfd3cd9ef034eed3d693683972c842576)

Change-Id: Icfa161109e76e2717f64084ddce829f6c68aeb57

commit_message:
Sync of new oslo-incubator libraries needed by image-tools.

Added to openstack-common.conf:
 - context
 - fixture
 - jsonutils
 - timeutils

Added by dependencies:
 - uuidutils (context)

Implements: blueprint image-tools

Change-Id: I5b6b35aa30d067b4fdac4b1ee72f0b49fe7137e4

'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-08-14 02:42:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Not quite sure I understand the argument here.  The columns to my knowledge are strictly for determining if an object is deleted or active.  I'm not sure I follow what this change gains us and I'm leery to make any DB change regardless of how trivial without some good justification.

The BP doesn't give much explanation/justification either, perhaps you could clarify what the advantage is here for me?"}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2013-08-14 04:53:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 7491, 'date': '2013-08-14 09:32:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Hello John.

The main objective of the blueprint is to provide unique constraints, based on database queries from cinder.db.sqlalchemy.api module.
We use `soft delete` in cinder so all deleted instaces just marks as `deleted=True` at the moment. To provide effective unique constraints we should add column `deleted` to unique constraint. This will cause problems, when we will delete instance, with same columns in UC as was deleted before.

For example, we have table `users` with (ud, name, deleted) columns. This table have UC on (name, deleted) columns. So if we
- add user with name 'a' (id=1, name='a', deleted=False)
- delete user with name 'a' (id=1, name='a', deleted=True)
- add one more user with name 'a' (id=2, name='a', deleted=False)
We will get an error when we will try to delete user with name='a' (id=2), because it's will conflict with UC on (name, deleted) columns.

To avoid this issue we set deleted=id on delete. 
Similar blueprint was already implemented in Nova (see https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/db-enforce-unique-keys)

Thanks, Victor."}, {'account_id': 7491, 'date': '2013-08-14 09:35:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-08-14 09:35:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 7491, 'date': '2013-08-14 09:36:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-14 10:27:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

But isn't the justification that your'e describing exactly why we switched to doing everything by UUID?  I still don't see the need or value.  Sorry if I'm being incredibly thick here."}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2013-08-16 00:46:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm also with John on this as I still understand the point of this change.  We require a primary key (volume uuid) to delete currently."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-23 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-23 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 7491, 'date': '2013-08-23 09:03:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Restored'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-08-23 16:10:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: No score

Even after a very long discussion in IRC I still am having trouble seeing the need for this.  The only concrete examples that were given were in service startup, which given the way the service is started I don't quite see how the described race would be encountered.

Regardless, I'm withdrawing my -1 as it seems there are a number of folks that understand this better than I do and seem to feel it's critical."}, {'account_id': 6802, 'date': '2013-08-29 11:19:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think that there are several places where the addition of unique constraints are reasonable (e.g., volume_type.name since the DB API implicitly assumes that names are unique), but I don't believe that this approach is the best way to go about achieving that objective. Partial indexes (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partial_index) are a much better approach in my opinion but unfortunately aren't supported by many database back ends.

Regardless, this blanket approach of changing all `deleted` types to be integer rather than boolean seems too broad. I'd prefer to see the changes (or at least justification for this patch) on a case-by-case basis instead."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-09-06 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-09-06 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Abandoned

Main issue is that we can't create unique constraint for columns, because
we are using soft deletion of entries (set `deleted` column to True).
The main idea is to use `deleted` columns to create unique constraint for
columns. For example (`col1`, `deleted`).
To make (`col1`, `deleted`) unique after entry deletion, we should assign the
value of `id` to `deleted` column.

Updated `openstack.common.db.sqlalchemy.utils` file (from Oslo).
Change type of `deleted` column from Boolean to table.id.type for all
tables in migration 017. Models, api functions, and tests modified.

Part of blueprint db-unique-keys

commit_message:
Alter column `deleted` type from bool to `id` type

We can't create unique constraint for columns, because we are using
soft deletion of entries (set `deleted` column to True).
The main idea is to use `deleted` columns to create unique constraint
for columns. For example (`col1`, `deleted`).
To make (`col1`, `deleted`) unique after entry deletion, we should
assign the value of `id` to `deleted` column.

Updated `openstack.common.db.sqlalchemy.utils` file (from Oslo). Added
required exception module.
Change type of `deleted` column from Boolean to table.id.type for all
tables in migration 017. Models, api functions, and tests modified.

Part of blueprint db-unique-keys

Change-Id: I37be5d97a890501fc1b31ddc0e2e6318c9d1eb7f

commit_message:
Don't change name of volume when selecting the image

Behaviour for "Create Volume" form changed.
Now it doesn't overwrite the user-specified values with
the name of the source image if user already
has written name for a new volume.

Fixes bug 1213953

'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-07-18 20:37:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

The change looks fine to me.  There does seem to be some edge cases where the versioning won't be taken into account if the GlanceImageService is initialized with a GlanceClientWrapper that was initialized with a hostname and a default version.  But that can be fixed later if it causes issues.

I added some Glance core reviewers to confirm that v1/v2 calls will have compatible returns from glanceclient."}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-07-26 12:38:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hey,

Thanks for the patch!

I like the idea but Ghe Rivero has been working on moving this code into glanceclient so, I'd suggest creating a new patch for glanceclient which depends on Ghe's and adds this feature rather than modifying nova's implementation.

You can check out Ghe's patch here: Ibb2c44df99ae5746e32695e69078737cc6b5aeeb

Cheers."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-07-26 18:00:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

See Flavio's comment"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-03 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

I would like to get some clarification from some glance-cores on this before dropping the -2'}, {'account_id': 5347, 'date': '2013-08-28 16:23:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

With the abandoning of Ghe's patch (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33327/) this approach needs to be revisited. But using V2 from Nova is more involved than just switching the version number because the workflow is different (e.g. in V1 an image can be created along with it's data in a single call, but V2 requires separate create and upload calls.) I suggest that:

1) The existing GlanceImageService class continue to be the interface between Nova and Glance.

2) Examine Nova code to see if all currently exposed features in that class are used (e.g. does Nova actually USE create with data) and remove any unused features to simplify.

3) Create pluggable glance handlers for V1 and V2. Selection of which would be a configuration on the GlanceImageService class. These handlers would map the image service calls into appropriate glanceclient calls. (e.g. a create with data in V1 handler maps directly to the V1 create, but in V2 handler maps to a create followed by an upload.)

4) Refactor as appropriate - I would suggest renaming GlanceImageService to just ImageService (esp. since there are some feature like download that are already pluggable to use non-glance functionality) and create GlanceV1ImageService and GlanceV2ImageService, perhaps from a common GlanceImageServiceBase class."}, {'account_id': 7701, 'date': '2013-08-29 11:44:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Thanks a lot for the review. Agree with the fact that the existing ImageService class needs a bit of refactoring. Though a small concern regarding your approach, if you look at the existing ImageService class, the methods that are called for all the actions, say delete/detail/show etc all pretty much do the same job of getting the relevant params and making the appropriate client call irrespective of whether its V1 or V2. So having separate ImageService classes for V1 or V2 would essentially mean having a lot of duplicated methods.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-09-06 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-09-06 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Adding glance-version in nova-conf

Nova should be configured to use either V1 or V2 of glance. Adds an
extra parameter in the conf to specify this value. Currently it is hardcoded
to 1 in all the glanceclient calls.

Change-Id: I50854015e5817de281936814e9b6b39639a6edf5
Implements: blueprint glanceclient-version-in-nova-conf

'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-08-15 10:33:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Interesting!  So, can we use this approach to kill the https://review.openstack.org/#/c/41854/ Fn::MemberListToMap thing?  Seems much better to have one more generic format-mangling function for use in the native templates?'}, {'account_id': 7385, 'date': '2013-08-16 12:09:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'll mark it as need fixing at least for the commit message, which is a bit too terse.

I'd like a little bit more reasoning for that feature as well. Having a generic template engine would be interesting, without having to resort to function calls in some places."}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-08-20 02:42:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hey guys,

Thomas totally agree: (I think this needs to be in a discussion phase)

Steven: at the moment this is still needed (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/41854/).
Jinja doesn't have powerful string functions so this is not easy to do. Although you can define your own jinja functions too. I really like jinja, too me it would be neat to use this instead of making our own in HOT."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-08-20 09:21:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

> Thomas totally agree: (I think this needs to be in a discussion phase)

Ok changing my +2 to a +1 pending further discussion then (maybe change this to a WIP or draft review and start a ML discussion?)

FWIW I would also much rather reuse an existing templating mechanism provided we can get sufficient consensus about which one, rather than having to maintain lots of special-purpose template functions indefinitely'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-08-22 17:04:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

Sorry to -2 this, but I think this is dangerous for two reasons.

First, jinja2 is not safe for arbitrary use by tenants. We would need to run this in a very tightly controlled forked process to be at all safe from malicious Heat users. Forgive me if I don't trust the jinja2 sandbox to prevent users from busting out and grabbing another user's authentication details from Heat's memory.

Also, I appreciate the desire for the feature, and think it does have a place. However, I emphatically believe that place is not in the Heat engine or HOT. Users can embed template content in Metadata and feed it to in-instance tools, which is where arbitrary code is completely safe as the users are already root there.

I'd like to keep Heat focused on orchestration, and provide the necessary interfaces and lightweight tools for instance configuration:

There is already a blueprint for just that:

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/native-tools-bootstrap-config"}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-08-22 22:13:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I totally understand the security concern. re: native tools I don't see what that has to do with it (the use cases I had in mind had nothing to do with metadata)."}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-08-23 18:08:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

If powerful templating isn't for files on instance disks, what is it for? Did I perhaps totally miss the use case explanation?"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-08-28 16:46:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Clint: it was for munging data from e.g. CloudFormation resource types to native ones so that we could implement as many as possible of the AWS:: resources using provider templates alone.'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-08-28 16:59:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It would be a lot easier to understand how that would work and why this is important with some examples.

That also doesn't really make me feel any better about the concerns I have already addressed. Unless there is some kind of restriction where only administrators can use jinja2."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-08-29 14:25:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Check out https://review.openstack.org/#/c/41016/2 (and read the comments) for an example.

FWIW I agree with your security concerns and I think we need to find a different solution to this problem. Angus added I68910c51eaeb0857531028e87b89b9192db4c8ba, but that's pretty limited - AAUI it only handles cases where

 [{X: x, Y: y}, ...] -> {x: y, ...}

and not the more common

 [{X: x, Y: y, Z: z, ...}, ...] -> [{A: x, B: y, C: z, ...}, ...]"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-09-06 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-09-06 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Enable multihost network with DHCP agent

This is phase one of multihost blureprint. This patch
enables the multihost network. Next phase will enable
multihost L3 router.

when a network is multihost one,
--addn-hosts is used to record all the dns entries of
the VMs of the network, --dhcp-hostsfile will only record
the VMs on local host.

Currently, we will have one DHCP IP for each DHCP enabled
subnet of multihost network on each host. Following patches
will consider use shared DHCP IP. Ml2, linuxbridge, and
OVS plugins are the fisrt plugins to support this feature.

Pure multihost network without multihost L3 router is valuable
for Use Case Single Flat Network in networking administration guide.

implements: blueprint quantum-multihost

Change-Id: I9b4b9e4d68829cf556b2cc32287cf8fc8472fc44

commit_message:
Correct server action confirm_resize v3 API return code

The confirm_resize method currently returns 204 instead of
the expected 202.  This change also removes unnecessary
returns when @wsgi.response() is used.

Fixes bug 1088695
DocImpact

Change-Id: I7481bf6ff944088057728fa3dd11f58d678d06f3

"}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2013-07-22 13:56:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

Just a couple comments. Were the changes being pulled in from Oslo-incubator landed in Oslo before the sync? I don't *think* we can make changes to keystone/openstack/common/* code without the changes landing in Oslo first before applying them to Keystone. 

https://github.com/openstack/oslo-incubator/blob/master/openstack/common/log.py#L158

It looks like this change contains some changes to Oslo as well as some changes to other things within Keystone. From a maintainability standpoint we might want to consider the following (each as it's own patch possibly): 

1.) Make the required changes to Oslo 
2.) Sync the change from Oslo to Keystone
3.) Apply any remaining changes to Keystone that use the recent changes from Oslo

The reason I suggest this is because it makes things a little more manageable if one of them needs to be reverted. Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 7491, 'date': '2013-07-23 06:50:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 7491, 'date': '2013-07-30 09:29:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Rebased'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-30 09:29:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Use common Oslo code for work with database

`keystone/common/sql/core.py`
Modified DictBase class - added common `models.ModelBase` class as
base class instead of object and removed duplicated code.
Used ping_listener() frunction from common oslo code instead of keystone
implementation.

`requirements.txt`
Added new oslo.config version

`keystone/common/config.py`
Removed options, that duplicates in common oslo config

`keystone/common/sql/migration.py`
`tests/backend_db2.conf`
`tests/backend_ldap_sql.conf`
`tests/backend_mysql.conf`
`tests/backend_postgresql.conf`
`tests/backend_sql.conf`
`tests/backend_sql_disk.conf`
Renamed `sql` section to `database`

blueprint use-common-oslo-db-code

Change-Id: I987f053f906df93914e85f0305ba26dd84c23901

commit_message:
Filter network by project id

Need filter the networks by project id when show the networks with
normal user

Fix bug 1186867

Change-Id: I10b5880070a569614f54fa7dbcf08e548bcbc924
(cherry picked from commit 2a7f08ae4abca51dc60a02deee06a108ad1c4dcc)

Conflicts:
	nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py
	nova/tests/db/test_db_api.py

Change-Id: Id4e07582526ad27c6e181e5d0618f6ded1a4a6cb

commit_message:
amend text in accordance to further review on 43650:

- re-word section, to do a better job of explaining that DHCP and L3 agents need Linux network namespace support if overlappping IP addresses are in use on the same host.

Change-Id: I867c7af8659044791c8b54cc3ebfaec73c9ae52f

[{'created': '2013-09-05 23:49:25.000000000', 'message': 'Run cfg.CONF.reset() on test cleanup

This means clear_override and clear_default do not
need to be called explicitly for each set_override and set_default
call.

This also fixes any potential test execution order issues
where an option has been set without being cleared at all.

Change-Id: Ic40c3be10b32eb3011bc0733cee9c1faaf8f1240
Fixes-Bug: #1221476
'}]
commit_message:
Run cfg.CONF.reset() on test cleanup

This means clear_override and clear_default do not
need to be called explicitly for each set_override and set_default
call.

This also fixes any potential test execution order issues
where an option has been set without being cleared at all.

Change-Id: Ic40c3be10b32eb3011bc0733cee9c1faaf8f1240
Fixes-Bug: #1221476

commit_message:
Fix TemplateResource list property conversion

In the convertion from "a,b,c" to ['a', 'b', 'c'] we are
not checking for the case of an empty list.

Change-Id: I834c4755abf33793a9484138f9dac97d7d8194da
Closes-bug: #1221009

This patch moves an exception from cinder.exception
into brick.exception to fix an import in remotefs.

Fixes Bug #1221309

Change-Id: I9b060c1e1129b3fe30145227712d0234e0f42504

commit_message:
Fix brick remotefs dependency on cinder

This patch moves an exception from cinder.exception
into brick.exception to fix an import in remotefs.

Fixes Bug #1221309

Change-Id: I9b060c1e1129b3fe30145227712d0234e0f42504

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-04 23:22:54.000000000', 'message': 'Engine, task, flow, patterns unification

Instead of keeping the existing flows with there functionality
move the existing flows to just be the thing that defines the
runtime structure. Have the action_engine translate these
structures into something useful, which in the case of action_engine
is translating the structures into things that are pretty much
like the existing flows (but not exactly).

Change-Id: I3a8b96179f336d1defe269728ebae0caa3d832d7

'}, {'created': '2013-09-05 21:59:59.000000000', 'message': 'Engine, task, linear_flow unification

In order to move away from the existing flows having their
own implementation of running, start moving the existing
flows to be  patterns that only structure tasks (and impose
constraints about how the group of tasks can run) in useful
ways.

Let the concept of running those patterns be handled by an
engine instead of being handled by the flow itself. This
will allow for varying engines to be able to run flows in
whichever way the engine chooses (as long as the constraints
set up by the flow are observed).

Currently threaded flow and graph flow are broken by this
commit, since they have not been converted to being a
structure of tasks + constraints. The existing engine has
not yet been modified to run those structures either, work
is underway  to remediate this.

Part of: blueprint patterns-and-engines

Followup bugs that must be addressed:
  Bug: 1221448

Change-Id: I3a8b96179f336d1defe269728ebae0caa3d832d7

commit_message:
Engine, task, linear_flow unification

In order to move away from the existing flows having their
own implementation of running, start moving the existing
flows to be  patterns that only structure tasks (and impose
constraints about how the group of tasks can run) in useful
ways.

Let the concept of running those patterns be handled by an
engine instead of being handled by the flow itself. This
will allow for varying engines to be able to run flows in
whichever way the engine chooses (as long as the constraints
set up by the flow are observed).

Currently threaded flow and graph flow are broken by this
commit, since they have not been converted to being a
structure of tasks + constraints. The existing engine has
not yet been modified to run those structures either, work
is underway  to remediate this.

Part of: blueprint patterns-and-engines

Followup bugs that must be addressed:
  Bug: 1221448
  Bug: 1221505

Change-Id: I3a8b96179f336d1defe269728ebae0caa3d832d7

while run tox -epy27 or run_tests.sh, webtest will be installed for

    % (key, type(environ[key]), environ[key]))

test method

tox -epy27 -- --tests=keystone.tests.test_associate_project_endpoint_extension

commit_message:
Install latest webtest for testing

while run tox -epy27 or run_tests.sh, webtest will be installed for
testing. But old version of webtest may induce many failures.
such as "PATH_INFO is not a string".

In latest webtest(2.0.7):
assert type(environ[key]) in METADATA_TYPE, (
    "Environmental variable %s is not a string: %r (value: %r)"
    % (key, type(environ[key]), environ[key]))

In old webtest(1.3.3):
assert type(environ[key]) is str, (
    "Environmental variable %s is not a string: %r (value: %r)"
    % (key, type(environ[key]), environ[key]))

Designate version for webtest in test-requirements.txt.

-----------
test method
-----------
tox -epy27 -- --tests=keystone.tests.test_associate_project_endpoint_extension
tox -epy27

Partial-Bug #1219808
Change-Id: I95b874584f2e4e9dff2cce182e454e2b72e2992e

commit_message:
Fix some errors of format string missing object type

Some format strings miss the object type like below:

 if CONF.logging_exception_prefix.find('%(asctime)') != -1:

The correct code should be .find('%(asctime)s').
This patch fixes this kind of errors in keystone.

1. Putting the agent modules inside:
neutron/services/firewall/agents/
and, the driver modules inside:
neutron/services/firewall/drivers/

2. change the title of this patch to reflect that agent as well

1) I left comments inline to clean python stylistic items.
2) Your usage of httplib is actually making more work than if you had used a higher level lib like requests or httplib2.

(5 inline comments)

My main issue is regarding the unit tests which are being skipped and whether the backend can be mocked in some way to get those to execute."}, {'account_id': 7576, 'date': '2013-09-04 05:10:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: (3 inline comments)

Regarding skipped test cases:

The agent code inherits L3_Agent class and firewall driver implements fwaas base. As you can see, these new files don't modify DB and __don't main internal state__. Their purpose is to translate neutron settings to our rest APIs, so the unit test cases were designed to check if firewall is properly configured. If the firewall is not deployed at all, any test coverage would probably be very trivial.

One possibility is to add some test cases to check the internal state of l3_agent or fwaas_plugin. It will be quite similar to test cases of reference design and they really just test reference design's code."}, {'account_id': 7576, 'date': '2013-09-04 05:49:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 7576, 'date': '2013-09-04 05:59:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

Updated the code based on comments.

I spent some time to look at how not to skip the test. It's quite impossible.

For example, process_router() is the only entrance to our L3 agent implementation. The first call is auth(), which is a rest call. The next segment is to read host interface to firewall internal interface mapping. It's another rest call. Its result, plist, is used for the next two function calls. Without this map, we can't do anything, as the firewall only understands its internal interface names."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-04 06:03:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGit#Test_Failures

This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. commit_message:
vArmour gateway agent and FWaaS driver

This patch enables vArmour's routing and firewall services to be deployed in
openstack environment.
- as gateway for internal networks
- support SNAT and DNAT (floating IP)
- FWaaS services

Implements: blueprint varmour-fwaas-driver
Change-Id: I6ddfa3137ed7e2a3fcf16a764d1340a8eae9359a

This is not finished but I would like feedback on whether or not it is on the right track before continuing.

What we now have is the ability to clone of volume. If the original volume is deleted, it is kept silently until all clones and snapshot of original are deleted. All this is managed using a lookup table stored in ceph.

Auto flatten is not implemented yet but should be easy to implement now this is in place if we want to go down that route.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-14 18:58:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

"}, {'account_id': 1107, 'date': '2013-08-15 01:58:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Do not merge

(2 inline comments)

In general I don't think this should be merged without some kind of auto-flattening, since it allows users to use up unbounded extra space from hidden clones.

i.e. if a user created a long chain of volumes cloned from each other (a->b->c->...), and deleted all but the last one, all of the parents would still be around taking up space.

Adding simple auto-flattening to this wouldn't be too hard though."}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2013-08-15 08:25:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1107, 'date': '2013-08-15 17:14:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-12 16:51:29.000000000', 'message': 'Added copy-on-write support for all RBD cloning

Up till no we had copy-on-write for volume snapshots only.
This change allows clone from volume to use copy-on-write
instead of a doing a full copy each time.

Implements: blueprint use-copy-on-write-for-all-volume-cloning
Fixes: bug #1209199

Change-Id: Ia4a8a10c797cda2cf1ef3a2e9bd49f8c084ec977

'}, {'created': '2013-08-16 14:37:01.000000000', 'message': 'Added copy-on-write support for all RBD cloning

Up till now we only had copy-on-write for cloning from snapshot. This
change optionally allows clone from volume to use copy-on-write
instead of a doing a full copy each time. This should increase speed
and reduce nearterm storage consumtion but could introduce some new
risks e.g. excessively long clone chains and flatten storms. To avoid
this, a new config option has been providedons are provided -
rbd_max_clone_depth - which allows the user to limit the depth of a
chain of clones i.e.

    a->b->c->d as opposed to a->b
                              ->c
                              ->d

This will avoid flatten storms by breaking chains as they are formed
and at an early, predefined stage.

A second option - rbd_clone_from_volume_force_copy - allows the user
to use a full copy as before i.e. disable COW for volume clones.

Implements: blueprint use-copy-on-write-for-all-volume-cloning
Fixes: bug #1209199

Change-Id: Ia4a8a10c797cda2cf1ef3a2e9bd49f8c084ec977
'}, {'created': '2013-08-16 14:47:32.000000000', 'message': 'Added copy-on-write support for all RBD cloning

commit_message:
Added copy-on-write support for all RBD cloning

Up till now we only had copy-on-write for cloning from snapshot. This
change optionally allows clone from volume to use copy-on-write
instead of a doing a full copy each time. This should increase speed
and reduce nearterm storage consumtion but could introduce some new
risks e.g. excessively long clone chains and flatten storms. To avoid
this, a new config option has been providedons are provided -
rbd_max_clone_depth - which allows the user to limit the depth of a
chain of clones i.e.

    a->b->c->d as opposed to a->b
                              ->c
                              ->d

This will avoid flatten storms by breaking chains as they are formed
and at an early, predefined stage.

A second option - rbd_clone_from_volume_force_copy - allows the user
to use a full copy as before i.e. disable COW for volume clones.

Implements: blueprint use-copy-on-write-for-all-volume-cloning
Fixes: bug #1209199

Change-Id: Ia4a8a10c797cda2cf1ef3a2e9bd49f8c084ec977

commit_message:
fix conversion type missing

Conversion type is missing in some places which would cause some
unexcepted error. By using 'grep -rn "%(\w\+)[^\%a-z0-9\.\-]"',
we could find all cases of '%(variable_a)' and fix them.

Change-Id: Id4b376a92ad23db2cb5380be85d4fe937f1a5cb7
Closes-Bug: #1221026

commit_message:
Add support for large_ops tempest test

This test launches a bunch of instances at once (in attempt to find any
performance/scale issues).  This is the regression test for bug 1199433

Set TEMPEST_LARGE_OPS_NUMBER, the number of instances to attempt to spawn at
once to 150.  The number 150 is picked via trial and error.  Before the
related bug was fixed, one couldn't even spawn 50 instances.

Change-Id: Ic9b4872ae9ecccff8b4876b4c9d9572cb1233081

messages:
[{'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-08-02 20:32:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

A couple things inline, but I think this looks okay.

For some reason, I'm kinda stuck on the new intermediate class  having "DB" in the name. Really, the only thing that distinguishes it from the base class is that it has a standard set of attributes that we store for things in the database. In an effort to really make this an insulation-from-the-database thing, should we call it something different? Like NovaFormalObject or NovaSuitAndTieObject?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-02 20:39:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me
